content.text: In its 99 years, the Millrose Games has never staged a women's race longer than a mile. Meet officials said yesterday there would be a women's 3,000-meter race -- almost two miles -- in this year's meet, Feb. 2 at Madison Square Garden, and the field would be led by the world's best women's distance runner.  She is 21-year-old Tirunesh Dibaba of Ethiopia, the first runner, male or female, to hold the world championships at 5,000 and 10,000 meters outdoors. She has also won three world championships in cross-country. Her opposition will include Jen Rhines, an American Olympian in 2004 and the national champion at 10,000 meters outdoors in 2005, and Sarah Hall, 12th for the United States in last year's world indoor championships.  FRANK LITSKY  SPORTS BRIEFING: TRACK AND FIELD
content.title: MILLROSE TO HOLD WOMEN'S 3,000

content.text: Reese Hoffa, John Godina, Christian Cantwell and Dan Taylor were named yesterday as the four-man field for the men's shot-put at the 100th annual Millrose Games on Feb. 2 at Madison Square Garden. Hoffa, ranked first in the world last year, will be seeking his third straight victory at the Millrose Games.  FRANK LITSKY  SPORTS BRIEFING: TRACK AND FIELD
content.title: MILLROSE SHOT-PUT FIELD SET

content.text: Maurice Greene and Gail Devers, two Americans who have won Olympic and world championships, were added yesterday to the field for the 100th annual Millrose Games Feb. 2 in Madison Square Garden. Greene, 32, will run in the men's 60-meter dash and Devers, 40, in the women's 60-meter hurdles.  FRANK LITSKY  SPORTS BRIEFING: TRACK AND FIELD
content.title: GREENE AND DEVERS JOIN MILLROSE FIELD

content.text: Forty-five of the world's top professional bull riders came to Manhattan this weekend for the Versus Invitational at Madison Square Garden, hoping to stay atop some of the nation's top bulls in the Professional Bull Riders tour's first visit to New York.  J. B. Mauney of Mooresville, N.C., last year's rookie of the year on the circuit, won the first event of his career by finishing fourth in the final round yesterday after a ride on a bull named The Boogerman. He and the second-place finisher, Steven Shelley, were the only two riders to score on all four of their bulls this weekend.  The three-time world champion Adriano Moraes of Brazil had won the first two rounds of competition Saturday, but he was thrown by his bull in the final round yesterday and finished third over all.  BULL RIDING
content.title: Rough Rides In the Big City

content.text: Alan Webb, the United States' most successful young middle-distance runner, will compete in three Eastern indoor meets the next three weekends. Webb had previously committed to the mile races in the New Balance Games on Saturday at the Armory in Upper Manhattan and the Reebok Boston Indoor Games on Jan. 27. Millrose Games officials said yesterday that Webb would run on Feb. 2 in their Wanamaker Mile at Madison Square Garden.  FRANK LITSKY  SPORTS BRIEFING: TRACK AND FIELD
content.title: WEBB TO RUN WANAMAKER

content.text: The Boston Marathon scored a coup yesterday when it added Deena Kastor, the 33-year-old American who ran the world's fastest time for a woman last year, to its April 16 race, which is six days before the London Marathon. It will be Kastor's Boston debut.  FRANK LITSKY  SPORTS BRIEFING: MARATHON
content.title: KASTOR TO RUN BOSTON

content.text: The first man into the quarterfinals of this year's Australian Open on Sunday was unseeded Mardy Fish, which was quite an achievement considering the former state of his forehand and his left wrist.  But Fish, long considered a talented yet unreliable player, has managed to recover from both those handicaps in the last two years with the help of two operations on his wrist and of his coaches Scott Humphries and Todd Martin, each a former Tour player.  Now Fish, 25, is in the final eight at a Grand Slam event for the first time, and, as the luck of the draw would have it, the man he will face is his childhood housemate Andy Roddick.  ''We were more like brothers than best friends,'' Fish said of the years he spent living with the Roddick family in Florida when he and Roddick were aspiring juniors.  Fish advanced Sunday with a 6-1, 7-6 (4), 2-6, 7-5 victory over 16th-seeded David Ferrer of Spain, who had beaten Fish in their two previous matches. Roddick advanced with another impressive performance under heavy pressure, winning by 6-3, 3-6, 6-1, 5-7, 6-4 against the net-rushing Mario Ancic of Croatia.  ''I knew in the fifth set, win or lose, I had to try to turn the tables on the aggression,'' said Roddick, who broke the ninth-seeded Ancic in the fifth game of the final set, then held that advantage, serving out the match in style and winning it with a backhand winner down the line.  That shot was a symbol of Roddick's revival in the last six months with the help of his new coach, Jimmy Connors, whose two-handed backhand was his signature shot. Connors was in the front row of Rod Laver Arena on Sunday, pounding on the wall as the sixth-seeded Roddick again came up with the clutch shots he required, just as he had in his third-round bout with the former Australian Open champion Marat Safin.  A year ago, in the fourth round on this same court, Roddick, erratic and confused, was upset by Marcos Baghdatis of Cyprus in four sets. This year, despite Ancic's constant pressure, Roddick passed the test and is now a heavy favorite to reach the semifinals in light of his current form and a 4-1 record against Fish.  ''It's always a little weird when we play each other because of our history,'' Roddick said.  In the fourth round, the Scottish teenager Andy Murray will have his dream matchup at the Australian Open, but it is not so certain that James Blake has his. Murray had been eagerly awaiting his first chance to match his fluid and fast-maturing all-court game against the slashing forehand and athleticism of Rafael Nadal, the leader of Murray's generation.  Murray granted his own wish by winning in straight sets, 6-3, 6-2, 6-4, against Juan Ignacio Chela of Argentina on Saturday. Chela overwhelmed Murray in the first round here last year.  But there will be no novelty for Blake when he faces Fernando González of Chile in the fourth round. They have played six times, and González has won the past three matches, all on quick surfaces.  ''He's given me problems the last few times, but I've had some success against him earlier in his career,'' Blake said. ''Hopefully, I can draw on that and get back to the winning ways against him. He's playing pretty confident right now as well.''  On Saturday, against his close friend Robby Ginepri, Blake had to save a set point in the first set, then saved four more set points in the second with Ginepri serving at 5-4. What will look like a straightforward 7-6 (7), 7-5, 6-2 victory on the draw sheet was hardly that.  Ginepri spent time around more than your average weekend hacker in the off-season, playing the latest of a series of exhibition matches against the retired Pete Sampras. ''He taught me a thing or two,'' said Ginepri, who added that Sampras had been thinking about playing one more Wimbledon.  ''There's been some talk about it, but you never know with that,'' Ginepri said. ''He left the sport in a magical way, so he wouldn't want to ruin that.''  TENNIS
content.title: Fish, Into Quarterfinals, Will Face Ex-Housemate

content.text: After two years of waiting and not much playing, Serena Williams is back in a final, and it happens to be in a Grand Slam tournament.  Williams continued the most surprising run of her career Thursday by defeating the 17-year-old Czech Nicole Vaidisova, 7-6 (5), 6-4, in the semifinals of the Australian Open, which she won in 2003 and 2005.  In 2003, Williams was the overwhelming favorite, having won the three previous Grand Slam tournaments. In 2005, she was still on the short list of contenders. This year, she was a true underdog, arriving here with a world ranking of 81, having played in only five tournaments in the last year.  Now, after beating five seeded players, including the 10th-seeded Vaidisova, she has put herself back at the center of the sport and guaranteed herself a place in the top 20.  ''I can't believe it; that's awesome,'' said Williams, whooping it up on court in her postmatch interview. ''That was so fast.''  Speedy indeed, but it took her more time than she would have liked to close out the powerful but erratic Vaidisova, a 6-foot blonde who left Europe to train at Nick Bollettieri's Tennis Academy in Bradenton, Fla., as a youngster, occasionally sneaking peeks at Williams's training sessions there.  Down by 1-5 in the second set, Vaidisova closed the gap to 4-5, saving five match points, before Williams finally closed out the 1-hour, 46-minute victory with a forehand volley winner.  Williams will face the winner of Thursday's second semifinal between top-seeded Maria Sharapova of Russia and No. 4 Kim Clijsters of Belgium, neither of whom has won this title.  As Williams walked through the corridors of Rod Laver Arena, minutes before walking on court, she saw her agent, Jill Smoller, who greeted her by clenching her fists and striking a muscle-beach pose and then giving her a roundhouse smack on the rear.  It was a sign of what makes Williams tick. This surprising run in Melbourne has been much more about desire than thorough preparation, much more about muscle memory and competitiveness than hard-won fitness.  Once on court against Vaidisova, it took time for Williams to bare her teeth. Despite the power being produced on both ends of the court, the pace was slow, almost reflective between the points, and the early games were long.  Vaidisova's game plan was clear early: attack Williams's second serves and try to move her -- not just side to side but back to front with the occasional drop shot. At the start, Vaidisova applied these principles well, breaking Williams's serve in the opening game after two deuces and then holding her own serve to go up, 2-0.  But Williams, who looked sluggish at times early, began moving and serving more convincingly -- she would finish with 10 aces -- and adjusting to Vaidisova's big returns.  Vaidisova, taking huge risks, began to produce more errors than winners with her forehand, with its huge backswing and relatively low margin for error. Williams broke her in the sixth game to get back on serve, but Vaidisova would still get her chance to win the set when she broke Williams again to go up, 5-4, and then served for the lead.  After saving a break point with an ace to get to deuce, she failed to put another first serve into play in the game, as Williams saved a set point with a big forehand that Vaidisova could not handle. It was soon 5-5 and then 6-6, with Williams jumping out to a 5-1 lead in the tie breaker and then holding on to win the set after Vaidisova rallied to 5-5, with Williams serving consecutive double faults at 5-2..  Vaidisova's pride and power in the tie breaker was foreshadowing for the second set when, apparently out of contention, she roared back, saving four match points on her serve at 3-5 and another on Williams's serve at 4-5 before she closed it out.  ''Almost did a gagarooni there,'' Williams said. ''Basically that means gagging. But she played some incredible points on match points, just got relaxed. She reminded me a little bit of myself.''  In late matches on Wednesday, Tommy Haas and Fernando González took radically different paths to their upset victories.  Haas had to win arguments with himself as well as win rallies, and had to fight through rough patches, swooping pigeons and even a match point before finally closing out Nikolay Davydenko of Russia, the world's third-ranked player, in five sets.  González, once again, could do little wrong, coming up with clutch serves and huge forehands on points big and small. He also kept the unforced errors that were once his trademarks to a minimum as he overwhelmed Rafael Nadal of Spain, the second-ranked player, in straight sets.  Though their methods and moods were disparate, the 10th-seeded González and the 12th-seeded Haas share a healthy perspective. They are both middle-aged for tennis stars -- Haas is a 28-year-old German, González a 26-year-old Chilean -- and both have had to wait their turn for the sort of breakthrough that prodigies like Nadal understandably take for granted.  Now these two flashy players with one-handed backhands will share the spotlight with each other in the semifinals Friday night at Rod Laver Arena. In the other semifinal, top-seeded Roger Federer was to face Andy Roddick on Thursday. Sharapova, seeded No. 1, and Clijsters, seeded fourth, both struggled yet prevailed on Wednesday. Clijsters, who has announced that this will be her last Australian Open, failed to control her power for significant stretches of the first and second sets, finishing with 62 unforced errors and 47 winners against the three-time champion Martina Hingis.  The last time Haas was in the final four of a Grand Slam was here in 2002, the same year he topped out at No. 2 in the rankings, the same year his right shoulder failed him, requiring two surgeries and knocking him out of the game for more than a year and out of contention for the major prizes until now.  Haas was the only man to push Federer to a fifth set in any Grand Slam last year, doing so here in the fourth round. He later lost to Davydenko in five sets in the quarterfinals of the United States Open, paying the toll for the two five-set victories that preceded the match.  He could have gone down swinging again this time if Davydenko had managed to return Haas's kicking second serve on his one and only match point at 4-5, 30-40 in the fifth set. But Davydenko went for too much and missed a backhand into the net.  Haas missed his first chance to close out the match when serving at 6-5, 40-15 when Davydenko successfully challenged a line call on a forehand that had been called out. But Haas converted on his next match point, moving to his left and hitting his signature running backhand down the line. That left the baseline-hugging Davydenko, usually the master of the full-swinging half volley, to lunge and miss as Haas won, 6-3, 2-6, 1-6, 6-1, 7-5.  González has become a familiar presence in the second week of Grand Slam events, but only early in the second week. He reached the quarterfinals at the 2002 United States Open, the quarterfinals of the 2003 French Open and even the quarterfinals in 2005 at Wimbledon.  But it has taken until now for the huge-hitting, soft-spoken González to take the next step into the semifinals, and he has done so in great style despite a meaty draw that required him to face Lleyton Hewitt in the third round and the supposedly red-hot James Blake in the fourth. Then came Nadal, the tenacious left-hander.  ''I'm delighted, but it's not over,'' González said after his 6-2, 6-4, 6-3 victory in which he never lost his serve, finishing with 41 winners, including 10 aces, and just 16 unforced errors.  Nadal has been the best player not named Roger Federer for the last two seasons, but he was not at his best Wednesday, finishing with seven more unforced errors than winners and failing to play the same sort of spectacularly effective defense that, along with his whipping forehand and combativeness, has defined him.  The reasons, according to Nadal, were González and the aftershocks of his marathon match with Andy Murray in the fourth round: a late-night five-setter that left him feeling soreness in his legs and pain in his upper left leg.  ''It was taking a lot of effort for me to run; I couldn't keep up with the rhythm of the match,'' Nadal said.  TENNIS
content.title: A Strong Run Leads Williams To the Finals In Australia

content.text: Barbaro might have been the story of 2006 in thoroughbred racing, but he was neither the Horse of the Year nor the 3-year-old champion. With his career cut short because of the fractured hind leg he sustained during the Preakness Stakes, voters for the Eclipse Awards decided he did not accomplish enough on the racetrack to merit any championship honors.  The winners of the awards, which honor the year's top performers in the industry, were announced last night in Beverly Hills, Calif.  In the voting for the 3-year-old male championship, Barbaro, the Kentucky Derby winner, came in a distant second to Bernardini, the winner of the Preakness, the Jim Dandy, the Travers and the Jockey Club Gold Cup.  Of the 271 votes cast -- by members of the National Turf Writers Association, employees of The Daily Racing Form and representatives of the National Thoroughbred Racing Association and Equibase -- 210 went to Bernardini. Barbaro received only 56 votes.  Barbaro did not fare any better in the voting for Horse of the Year, although he received more votes in that category than Bernardini. The winner was Invasor, who won all four of his North American starts in 2006, including the Breeders' Cup Classic (he defeated Bernardini). Invasor received 228 votes, to 21 for Barbaro and 16 for Bernardini.  The Barbaro team was not shut out, however. His jockey and his owners were named Eclipse winners.  Barbaro's regular rider, Edgar Prado, won an Eclipse Award as the nation's outstanding jockey.  Barbaro's owners, Roy and Gretchen Jackson, shared an award with Darley Stable as the nation's top owners.  It was previously announced that the Jacksons and the George D. Widener Hospital for Large Animals in Kennett Square, Pa., where Barbaro has been treated since breaking down in the Preakness on May 20, would receive a special Eclipse Award for their contributions to the sport.  There were no unanimous winners, but a handful of horses came close to sweeping the voting in their divisions. The Breeders' Cup juvenile filly winner, Dreaming of Anna, received 265 of the 270 votes in the 2-year-old filly division, and Invasor defeated Lava Man by a 262-8 margin in voting for the nation's outstanding older male.  With 213 votes, Fleet Indian was an easy winner in the older filly and mare category, becoming only the third New York-bred horse to win an Eclipse Award.  The closest race was in the male turf division. The Breeders' Cup Mile winner, Miesque's Approval, was the top vote-getter with 74, 5 more than The Tin Man. English Channel was third, with 63 votes.  Despite missing the final six days of the year after his suspension for a medication violation, Todd Pletcher won his third consecutive Eclipse Award as the nation's outstanding trainer.  Pletcher set records in 2006 for the most single-season earnings by a stable, the most stakes victories and the most graded stakes victories.  The other winners were Street Sense, 2-year-old male; Wait a While, 3-year-old filly; Thor's Echo, sprinter; Ouija Board, female turf; McDynamo, steeplechase; Adena Springs, breeder; and Julien Leparoux, apprentice jockey.  Street Sense's team will try to help him become the first Breeders' Cup juvenile champion to win the Kentucky Derby, and the first 2-year-old champion to win the Derby since Spectacular Bid in 1980.  HORSE RACING
content.title: Barbaro Loses to Rivals At the Eclipse Awards

content.text: With his spectacular performance in the long program at the United States Figure Skating Championships on Saturday night, Evan Lysacek did far more than wow a crowd and a set of judges to win a national title. He helped the men's field upstage the women's, a rarity in a sport in which tiny girls generally dominate the spotlight.  By landing a quad jump for the first time and posting the third-highest score ever under the sport's new judging system, Lysacek became a serious threat to win at the world championships in March in Tokyo. (No American man has won a world title since Todd Eldredge in 1996.)  To that, the newly confident Lysacek said, ''Bring it on.''  The American women are not shrinking from the scene, and Kimmie Meissner, 17, may well successfully defend her surprising world championship from a year ago. But Meissner's victory at the national championships was not close to the level of Lysacek's. Meissner needed Emily Hughes to fall midway through her long program to hold on for victory.  And without the veteran skaters Sasha Cohen and Michelle Kwan -- who are sitting out competition, at least for this season -- the United States women's team heads to Tokyo with little in the way of international swagger.  But Lysacek, 21, has given the men a shot of adrenaline. Until Saturday, he had labored to topple the three-time United States champion Johnny Weir at nationals, although he has been more successful than Weir internationally, winning bronze medals at the past two world championships.  But even Lysacek said he had not been a legitimate contender, watching the skating of Evgeni Plushenko of Russia and Stéphane Lambiel of Switzerland while in awe.  ''It's kind of like, honestly, I don't really know what I'm doing,'' Lysacek said. ''I'm out there thinking maybe this will work, maybe this will get me some points. So I was trying to learn, trying to learn from Evgeni Plushenko, trying to learn from the Swiss guy, Lambiel, all these guys who have been doing it longer than me.''  Neither Plushenko nor Lambiel will compete at the world championships, having taken the post-Olympic year off. The current world leader is Brian Joubert of France.  The biggest hurdle Lysacek has had to clear is the quad jump, which is considered a necessity for winning at the worlds or at the Olympics. Joubert has done as many as three in a program. Lysacek attempted one in last year's world championships, but he two-footed the landing.  At nationals, he not only landed it cleanly in his long program, but he also did it in combination with a triple toe loop.  Now that Lysacek has the quad in his arsenal, he says he feels confident he can defeat Joubert, who is less than graceful between his huge jumps.  ''I think that he has sort of dominated international skating this season, but only because I think it's sort of a transitional period for a lot of countries and he came out like gangbusters and he's been doing the quad for probably four seasons,'' Lysacek said. ''I know I have scored much higher than him in presentation almost every time we've competed against each other. There are areas of my skating that are stronger than his.''  Lysacek's success with the quad has pushed Weir to accomplish one. He two-footed the landing on his attempt while finishing third Saturday night, but he said he was encouraged.  ''Going into it, I wasn't sure: Should I do a triple, should I do a flourish, should I do a Biellmann, what should I do?'' Weir said. ''And I went for the quad and ended up on my feet and that was good.''  Ryan Bradley did not attempt a quad in his second-place performance, but said he hoped to add it soon as well.  Bradley, 23, arrived relatively late to the top tier of American men -- finishing eighth at nationals last year and nearly quitting in discouragement a few years ago. But he is an energetic crowd-pleaser, and he will see how well that style goes over with international judges for the first time in Tokyo.  Lysacek, a known quantity internationally, is eager to raise his profile nationally and may borrow a bit of glamour from his new girlfriend, the ice dancer Tanith Belbin. She and Ben Agosto won a silver medal in last year's Olympics and won their fourth national title here.  But Lysacek's first title was the talk of the championships. Even the women had to step aside.  FIGURE SKATING
content.title: With Quad, Lysacek Gives U.S. Men a Lift

content.text: Added to the Winter X Games 10 years ago as an appeal to youth, skiercross has instead come to be dominated by retired Alpine racers creating a second act to their competitive careers.  A new event for the 2010 Olympic Winter Games in Vancouver, skiercross features four or more racers on a downhill course of big jumps, banks and rollers. Often compared to motocross, competitors bump and jostle one another, leading to some spectacular crashes.  At the X Games on Sunday, the sport lived up to its reputation for contact on Buttermilk Mountain's 3,600-foot course. Nine of 24 racers fell -- three were treated at a hospital and released -- beginning with elimination rounds and carrying into a thrilling final. In that race, the Aspen skier Casey Puckett grabbed the lead out of the gate and hung on to win despite a late charge by Jake Fiala of Frisco, Colo.  Coming off the course's last jump, where the snowboardcross racer Lindsey Jacobellis wiped out a day earlier, Fiala made a final push to finish first, but he got his tips up while airborne and went skidding to the snow. His momentum carried him across the finish line, and he wound up with the silver medal.  ''I knew if I went too far to the left, I wouldn't make the landing,'' said Fiala, 31, who competed in Alpine events at the 2002 Olympics. ''I pretty much flew into the fence.''  Puckett, 34, who competed in downhill events at four Olympics from 1992 through 2002, said of Fiala's late push, ''I don't want to put people into the fence, but I'm going to protect my lead.''  Enak Gavaggio, 30, of France finished third, his seventh bronze medal at the Winter X Games. All three women's medalists were French: Ophelie David (gold), Valentine Scuotto (silver) and Meryll Boulangeat (bronze).  The most successful and famous racer in the field was the 33-year-old Daron Rahlves, of Sugarbowl, Calif., who has 28 Alpine World Cup podium appearances in downhill and super-G, including 12 victories. Rahlves retired from Alpine competition after the 2006 Olympics, his third.  Although it was his first Winter X Games, Rahlves was favored to win the gold medal in skiercross after finishing first in qualifying and in each of his quarterfinal and semifinal heats.  But during the final, Rahlves inexplicably lost his balance on an upper portion of the course and went careering sideways off a jump, crashing and losing a ski.  His spill demonstrated how unpredictable skiercross can be.  ''The big thing is,'' Puckett said, ''you can be the fastest skier in the world, which Daron arguably is, and still not win the skiercross.''  Its simplicity and unpredictability led Ron Semiao, the senior vice president of ESPN Original Entertainment and X Games creator, to add the event for the Winter X Games's second season. No skiing events were held during the first Winter X Games in 1997 because the sport was viewed as stale and stodgy compared with snowboarding.  Since its debut at the X Games, skiercross has become a World Cup discipline governed by the International Ski Federation.  But the sport's biggest boost was its inclusion in the next Winter Olympics. Skiercross will be the third X Games event to be added to the Olympics, joining snowboarding halfpipe and snowboardcross.  Later Sunday, with the biggest, most stylish 1080-degree spins, Steve Fischer wound back the clock during the men's superpipe, winning the gold medal.  Fischer, 24, of Breckenridge, Colo., last won X Games gold in 2004 when he was among a select group of riders who pioneered the 1080, a spin of three full rotations. He has since struggled, finishing out of the top 10 at the X Games, and failing to qualify for the 2006 Olympic team.  But in the X Games final, Fischer beat out three American Olympians, including the halfpipe gold medal winner at the Turin Games, Shaun White, who wound up with silver.  ''It's nice to be on top,'' Fischer said. ''This one is great.''  The first of Fischer's three runs turned out to be the winner, with a score of 92. White was second with a 91, and 19-year-old Mason Aguirre of Duluth, Minn., won the bronze with a 90.66.  Since Fischer helped introduce the 1080 three years ago, it has become a requirement for a winning run. All three medal winners included at least two during their routines.  As it turned out, an easier trick undid White.  Because White, 20, of Carlsbad, Calif., finished first in qualifying, he had the last run and a chance to unseat Fischer for gold. He could do no worse than second, but on his final run he landed low on a 540-degree spin known as a McTwist, a relatively midlevel move. On his prior run, White's board struck the deck during a McTwist.  ''I had a sketch, and that's what cost me gold,'' said White, who has not competed in a halfpipe contest since winning the U.S. Open of Snowboarding in March 2006. White has been inundated with commercial opportunities since winning Olympic gold, and he said they have interfered with his riding.  EXTREME SPORTS
content.title: Skiercross a Great Place To Bump Into Olympians

content.text: Tirunesh Dibaba, a 21-year-old Ethiopian, likes running in Boston, and who can blame her?  Two years ago, in the Reebok Boston Indoor Games, she set a world record of 14 minutes 32.95 seconds for the 5,000 meters. Saturday night, in the same meet before a near-capacity crowd of 4,000 at the Reggie Lewis Center, she lowered the record to 14:27.42.  The world record outdoors is 14:24.53 by Meseret Defar, another Ethiopian, who ran here in the 3,000 meters and won in 8:30.31, the fifth-fastest time ever. Shalane Flanagan finished a strong second in 8:33.25, an American record.  Had Defar raced against Dibaba, the excitement could have been overwhelming. But meet officials, aware of the popularity of distance racing here and the ticket-buying support of the city's large Ethiopian community, opted to have the women run in different distance races.  The women's exploits overshadowed the men's mile, even though that event created an excitement of its own. Alan Webb, who ran his indoor best of 3:56.70 a week ago at the New Balance Track & Field Center in Upper Manhattan, lowered that mark to 3:55.18. He led by as much as 30 meters and won by 18 meters over Kevin Sullivan of Canada (3:57.33). Next up for Webb is the Wanamaker Mile in the 100th annual Millrose Games on Friday night at Madison Square Garden.  This was the first major meet of the American indoor track season. Of the six runners in the women's 5,000, three were Ethiopians and two of the three others were rabbits.  There was little doubt who would win. From the start, Dibaba and her 24-year-old sister, Ejegayehu, pressed the pace. By 2,600 meters, the rabbits were gone and Tirunesh started pulling away from her sister.  On her last time around the fast 200-meter track, she lapped her sister, sprinted the final 200 meters in 29.72 seconds and won, looking as strong as when she had started. Then she collected her rewards: an Ethiopian flag, a bottle of water and a $25,000 check for breaking a world record.  ''I'm very happy about what I accomplished,'' she said through an interpreter. ''I was so prepared. I didn't do any cross-country because I was concentrating on this race, so I had the confidence to break the record. With two laps to go, I knew I would do it, but I didn't think I would do it by this much.''  In the men's mile, Webb had high expectations and lived up to them. He burst out at the start behind Moise Joseph of Haiti, the rabbit, ran the first quarter-mile in 55.3 seconds and left the others 20 meters behind.  ''I don't know why anyone would be surprised,'' Webb said. ''At 250 meters, I was a loner. I think my strength is really good.  ''I think I'm just getting used to running this fast. I have the ability to run fast indoors because that strength is inside of me.''  NOTES  The men's winners included Shawn Crawford in the 60-meter dash (6.55 seconds), David Payne in the 60-meter hurdles (7.58 seconds), Nick Symmonds in the 800 meters (1:48.15), the 40-year-old Mark Coogan in the masters mile (4:24.71), Craig Mottram of Australia in the 3,000 (7:39.24), Steven Hooker of Australia in the pole vault (19 feet  3/4 inch) and Dan Taylor in the shot-put (70-9 1/4, his best ever indoors). Among the women's winners were Sarah Jamieson of Australia in the mile (4:28.03), Marshevet Hooker in the 60 (7.24 seconds), Perdita Felicien of Canada in the 60 hurdles (7.97 seconds), Monica Hargrove in the 400 (52.85) and Jenn Stuczynski in the pole vault (15-3 1/4). Mottram, Hooker and Jamieson set Australian indoor records.  TRACK
content.title: Record Day for Women Highlights Reebok Games

content.text: Her long program Saturday was not the triumphant performance Kimmie Meissner had hoped for, but after holding on to win the women's title at the United States Figure Skating Championships, she could not stand still. She bounced in place, shifted from one skate to the other and clasped her hands to keep them still. She could not stop smiling.  With a narrow victory over a shaky field, Meissner, 17, captured her first national title, a year after her surprising victory at the world championships.  ''It's really neat,'' said Meissner, who defeated Emily Hughes by less than a point, 181.68 to 180.86. ''I was just getting used to the world champion thing and now this is going to be a new one. I'm really excited.''  As Meissner battled her nervous energy, she understood that she had not swept away the field, which was missing the sport's biggest names, Michelle Kwan and Sasha Cohen. Neither has officially retired, but Kwan and Cohen sat out this season to contemplate their futures.  In their absence, Meissner became the clear favorite, armed with her world title and a technically superior program. But Meissner had to hold off Hughes, whose fall on a triple flip probably kept her from winning. Alissa Czisny, 19, won the long program with 119.59 points, but because she was fifth after the short program Thursday night, she was able to move only as high as third.  Hughes, who turned 18 on Friday, said she understood how close she had come to winning this title, something her sister Sarah, the 2002 Olympic gold medalist, never did. ''I am aware,'' she said, ''and it is going to push me until March.''  That is when Meissner, Hughes and Czisny will compete as the United States women's team at the world championships in Tokyo against a strong field of Japanese contenders, including the 16-year-old sensation Mao Asada.  By then, Meissner hopes to have a triple axel back in her program. She has not landed one since the 2005 nationals, when she became the first woman to accomplish the feat since Tonya Harding in 1991.  ''We think about it every day,'' Meissner's coach, Pam Gregory, said. ''She practices it every day. It's just a matter of what the odds are. It can't be something that just comes together at the end. I know Kimmie, and consistency is the name of the game for her, and that's what allows her to be a good competitor.''  That consistency is why Meissner was surprised at her stumbles in the long program. On her first jump, which was supposed to be a triple-triple combination, she put her hand down on the landing of the triple lutz and went without the combination. She later wobbled on the landing of a combination. ''Of course I would have liked to have won the long program, but I'm happy over all,'' Meissner said. ''I'm glad I did a good short and I did a pretty good long. Not perfect, but pretty good.''  Czisny skated first in the final group Saturday and put on a spectacular performance, landing all of her jumps and capitalizing on her strength, her mesmerizing spins. A year ago, Czisny came to nationals believing she was a contender for the Olympic team, but she faltered, finishing seventh.  ''After last year I was so disappointed, so just coming back this year and skating well, I was really, really happy,'' Czisny said.  Meissner's performance left the door open for Hughes. But midway through Hughes's program, she fell on a triple flip, a jump she says she has struggled with recently.  ''I really wanted to skate a clean long program,'' she said. ''But what I've learned over the past year is, I learned to get up and keep going.''  Hughes had been in the lead at the Cup of China after the short program, only to falter in the long and fall to third. At Skate America, she failed to attempt several of her jumps in the long program and fell out of contention.  Meissner's stumbles this season have generally come in the short program, so she was relieved when she came out of that cleanly and holding a strong lead. She needed every bit of it.  Now that Meissner has a national title to go with her world championship, she plans to share the news with her classmates at Fallston High School in Bel Air, Md., when she returns to classes Tuesday.  She can tell them over the intercom because she is the student who makes the announcements.  Meissner said she would say: ''Kimmie Meissner is back in the building today after winning nationals, so make sure that when you see her you tell her congratulations. And this is Kimmie.''  With that, Meissner laughed and bounced along on her way to collect her champion's medal.  LYSACEK TAKES MEN'S TITLE -- Evan Lysacek won his first national title Saturday after finishing second and third the past two years. Although Lysacek has placed ahead of Johnny Weir in recent international competitions, he has been unable to top Weir, who had won the last three titles, at the nationals. Ryan Bradley finished second, and Weir third.  Lysacek landed the first quad jump of his career in the competition, doing a quad toe loop-triple toe loop combination on the first jump of his program. He also completed eight triple jumps, all cleanly.  ITALIAN WINS EUROPEAN TITLE -- Carolina Kostner landed six triple jumps to become the first Italian to win the women's title Saturday at the European Figure Skating Championships in Warsaw. (AP)  WINTER SPORTS
content.title: Meissner Slips but Holds Off Hughes for U.S. Title

content.text: The excellent news just kept coming for Lucie Safarova at the Australian Open. No sooner had she stunned herself and second-seeded Amélie Mauresmo by winning their fourth-round match, 6-4, 6-3, when she was informed that her boyfriend, Tomas Berdych, had also won his match.  ''Wow! Great,'' she said. ''We're going to have to celebrate.''  Mauresmo was the one celebrating in Melbourne last year, after winning her first Grand Slam singles title 13 years after she turned professional.  But this season is off to a much less auspicious start for Mauresmo, thanks to Safarova, a 19-year-old left-hander from the Czech Republic who generates plenty of racket-head speed with quick cuts at her ground strokes and first serves.  The match was not the only women's upset Sunday. Third-seeded Svetlana Kuznetsova of Russia, the 2004 United States Open champion, fell to No. 16 Shahar Peer of Israel, 6-4, 6-2. Peer will play the winner of Sunday's late match between 11th-seeded Jelena Jankovic of Serbia and Serena Williams.  Playing her first match at Rod Laver Arena, Safarova served notice that she was a threat by forcing Mauresmo to save two break points in her opening service game. Mauresmo appeared to take the hint, stabilizing her game to take a 4-1 lead, but her lack of depth on her topspin ground strokes soon became a problem. Safarova began finding the corners and pushing forward to the net with success.  Safarova won 18 of the last 21 points of the set, and she soon took a 4-1 lead in the second. But Mauresmo did not go meekly. She broke Safarova's serve in the next game, then held her own after a successful challenge of a serve that had been called out. The momentum was shifting, and it was soon 4-3 -- often a cue for the inexperienced player on the verge of a major upset to begin overthinking and overhitting.  But Safarova held firm to hold serve, then held even firmer in the final game of the match, recovering from the disappointment of failing to convert her first two match points on Mauresmo's serve. The last point was a microcosm of the match as Safarova nailed a short forehand into Mauresmo's backhand corner and followed it into the net, getting a passing shot into the net as a reward.  ''It's amazing; I still can't believe it,'' Safarova said. ''Warming up in the morning, I was saying like, wow, this a big court. But I felt really comfortable here.''  Until this tournament, Safarova's record in Grand Slam tournaments was 1-5, but her comprehensive 6-3, 6-3 victory against the combative Italian Francesca Schiavone, seeded 14th, in the second round was a sign of major progress. And now she is into the quarterfinals, where she will face No. 10 Nicole Vaidisova of the Czech Republic, who defeated seventh-seeded Elena Dementieva of Russia, 6-3, 6-3.  After six days of difficult weather, Sunday's conditions were blustery but relatively cool and sunny. There was no play at all on the outside courts on Saturday because of rain, a challenge for the organizers.  Eighth-seeded David Nalbandian of Argentina saved three match points before beating Sébastien Grosjean of France in five sets Saturday. Nalbandian will face Tommy Haas, who defeated his fellow German Florian Mayer in straight sets Sunday.  The huge-hitting Berdych, Safarova's boyfriend of four years, also had to wait a day before facing Dmitry Tursunov, but he should not be too leg weary when he plays No. 3 Nikolay Davydenko on Monday. Berdych, seeded 13th, needed little more than an hour to eliminate the ailing Tursunov of Russia, 6-2, 6-1, 6-1.  Li Na of China, seeded 19th, advanced quickly Sunday, defeating ninth-seeded Dinara Safina of Russia, 6-2, 6-2. Li has reached the fourth round or better in three consecutive Grand Slam events, and she could pose a serious threat to her next opponent, Martina Hingis.  Patty Schnyder will face the rising Russian Anna Chakvetadze, who defeated Jelena Kostanic Tosic, 6-4, 6-4. Kim Clijsters will face Daniela Hantuchova of the Slovak Republic, who survived a threat from the unseeded American Ashley Harkleroad. Down by a set and by 0-4 in the second, Hantuchova went on to win, 6-7 (6), 7-5, 6-3, leaving Harkleroad sobbing into her towel in her chair on Show Court Three.  TENNIS
content.title: An Unseeded Czech Foils Mauresmo's Repeat Bid

content.text: An obituary on Jan. 2 about Sydney Wooderson, a British runner who once held the world record for the mile, misstated the name of the federation that did not recognize a 1938 record for the 4:04.4 mile set by Glenn Cunningham at Dartmouth. It was the International Amateur Athletic Federation, not Athletics.  The obituary also referred incompletely to the reasons given by the federation for rejecting the record. It did not recognize any indoor records until 1987, and it has never recognized indoor records set on tracks with laps longer than 220 yards; the Dartmouth track was 264 yards a lap. (As the obituary noted, the federation also rejected the record because Cunningham used four different quarter milers to pace him.)
content.title: Corrections

content.text: In a stunning repeat of her performance at the Winter Olympics, Lindsey Jacobellis had to settle for a silver medal Saturday after falling just before the finish during the snowboarder X final at the Winter X Games.  Jacobellis led most of the way down the winding, jump-filled X Games course but lost her balance and flailed her arms while soaring over the final jump. Upon landing, she caught her heel edge and cartwheeled across the finish line, but not before Joanie Anderson passed her for the gold medal.  The gift from Jacobellis left Anderson thrilled. ''I'm so stoked and shocked,'' Anderson said.  It was reminiscent of the Olympic snowboardcross final in Turin, Italy, last year. Snowboardcross was a new event at the 2006 Olympics, and Jacobellis was favored to win its first gold medal.  But with a commanding lead in the Olympic final, Jacobellis celebrated early on the course's penultimate jump by pulling a stylish move called a method air; she grabbed her board's heel edge and tweaked it 75 degrees.  She caught an edge on the landing and spun on her back, allowing Tanja Frieden of Switzerland to pass her for the gold medal.  At first Jacobellis said her move was an attempt to stabilize her ride, but she later admitted she was just trying to have fun. Questions about her fall continued during the run-up to the X Games. And Jacobellis made it clear she was tired of them. During a recent interview, she said of the Olympic incident, ''It was just kind of a fluke thing that happened.''  Jacobellis has been the dominant performer in women's snowboardcross. She had not lost in the past three X Games in which she competed, from 2003 to 2005. Two weeks ago in Arona, Switzerland, she won her second consecutive world championship.  But with her latest tumble, Jacobellis has earned a reputation for blunders on her sport's biggest stages.  It has been a difficult week for Jacobellis, who declined to talk to reporters after Saturday's mishap. She sustained a concussion after a fall Thursday night during practice for the women's superpipe. She withdrew from the event but showed no lingering effects Saturday in racing to an early lead among the six riders in the snowboarder X final.  Half the field, including Frieden, wiped out earlier in the final on an upper portion of the course, making it a three-way race between Jacobellis, Anderson and Maelle Ricker.  Winter X Games
content.title: With Gold in Reach, Jacobellis Falls Again

content.text: For nearly two sets in his first official match of the year, Andy Roddick looked as if he just might be in for another nasty surprise at the Australian Open.  The first Grand Slam event of the season is a place of decidedly mixed memories for Roddick. It was here that he came of age, winning one of the matches of the decade against Younes el-Aynaoui of Morocco in the 2003 quarterfinals.  But this is also the rubberized place where trouble has surfaced in a hurry. In 2002, he twisted his ankle in the second round and had to default. Last year, the unproven Marcos Baghdatis stunned Roddick in four sets in the fourth round and kept him in the downward spiral that ended with his temporarily falling out of the top 10.  Despite having beaten No. 1 Roger Federer in an exhibition less than 48 hours earlier, Roddick found himself down a set against Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France on Monday after losing the first in a marathon tie breaker.  Roddick then found himself down, 2-5, in the second set before he came back and closed out the match, 6-7 (18), 7-6 (2), 6-3, 6-3.  Tsonga, an often-injured player ranked 212th, kept cranking serves and forehands like a member of the current elite and attacking the net like an old Australian great.  Was Roddick scared? ''To say the least, absolutely,'' he said.  But the nerves ended up having more impact on the less-experienced power player, and after Roddick held serve at love to get back to 5-3, Tsonga stepped to the line in Vodafone Arena to serve for a two-set lead and failed to win a point.  This first-round match would not be the same after that. Roddick took quick control in the ensuing tie breaker to even the score at one set apiece, then won the next two sets easily.  ''I think I got a little first-round jitters there; it's good to get through,'' said the sixth-seeded Roddick, who will face another Frenchman, Marc Gicquel, in the next round.  Federer had a jitter or two of his own in the early going as he started the defense of his title against Bjorn Phau of Germany before winning, 7-5, 6-0, 6-4.  Phau was one of the few men on tour to have a winning record against Federer, the world's dominant player, but his victory in their only previous match came in 1999. Federer was still a teenager then, trying to find a way to blend all his gifts into the ideal tennis package.  This time, Phau had to settle for breaking Federer's serve three times in the opening set, which he eventually lost.  Federer acknowledged he was a little nervous. ''That's not the usual for me,'' he said. ''But he played well, and I had to play good tennis to come through.''  Federer changed his January habits this year, skipping the tournament in Doha, Qatar, and instead preparing for the Australian Open by playing in the eight-man exhibition tournament, the Kooyong Classic, in Melbourne.  It was there that Roddick beat him, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3, in a high-quality final Saturday. Roddick had not defeated Federer in more than three years; in November, Federer had to save three match points to beat him in the Masters Cup in Shanghai. Saturday's match, however, does not count in the official Tour statistics because it was an exhibition.  ''I think it needs to be done on a big stage before you put too much emphasis on it,'' Roddick said.  What should be of some solace to the chase pack is that Federer has had more difficulty in Melbourne than at Wimbledon or the United States Open. He was beaten in the semifinals in 2005 by Marat Safin, who is back in the tournament after missing it last year with a knee injury. This was the only Grand Slam tournament last year in which Federer was pushed to five sets, going the distance against Tommy Haas in the fourth round.  It is also easier to imagine Rafael Nadal, the closest thing Federer has to a rival, doing more damage to Federer here on this relatively high-bouncing court, which is well suited to his heavy spin and fast footwork.  But Nadal, who has not won a singles title since beating Federer in last year's French Open final, remains in more questionable form than Federer, although he said that the groin strain that led him to withdraw from the Sydney event was not a concern.  He also has an intriguing first-round match Tuesday against Robert Kendrick of the United States, who nearly served and volleyed the Spaniard out of Wimbledon last year.  In the women's event, Amélie Mauresmo opened the defense of her title by defeating Shenay Perry of the United States, 6-3, 6-4, in the opening match on Rod Laver Arena. Mauresmo and Perry were the first players in Australian Open history to make use of electronic line calling. The Australians, following the lead of the United States Open, have introduced the system this year, but it has only been installed in Laver Arena.  Roddick, playing on the tournament's secondary show court, had to make do with the old-fashioned way, and he showed little tolerance for human error, exchanging words frequently with the chair umpire.  The mood outside the arena during Roddick's match was even more volatile as more than 100 fans were ejected after groups of Serbian and Croat supporters scuffled outside a merchandising tent.  Back on court, there were only shouts and murmurs and the occasional heated glance, as Roddick looked askance at Tsonga as the young Frenchman celebrated his successes with bellows of delight and fist pumps. Perhaps Roddick would have been more tolerant if he knew all that Tsonga had been through to get back into a Grand Slam draw.  He finished No. 2 in the world junior rankings in 2003 behind Baghdatis and was considered a key member of the young French generation that includes Richard Gasquet and Gaël Monfils. But Tsonga's career would soon be delayed by a herniated disk in his back, then by shoulder injuries. This was only the second Grand Slam singles match of Tsonga's career; coincidentally, the first one was also against Roddick, which he lost in straight sets at the 2005 French Open.  Roddick succeeded Monday without his coach, Jimmy Connors, who has remained in the United States to mourn the death of his mother and coach, Gloria.  ''I've talked to him every day since I've been here,'' said Roddick, who is unsure if Connors will eventually make the long journey to join him.  ''When we talk, we talk tennis,'' Roddick said. ''The last thing I'm concerned with right now is putting pressure on him.''  TENNIS
content.title: After an Early Scare, Roddick Takes Control

content.text: Evan Lysacek charged into his long program at the United States Figure Skating Championships, landed the first quad jump of his career to go with eight triple jumps and brought the Spokane Arena crowd to a thunderous celebration in winning his first national title Saturday night.  The quad toe loop came on Lysacek's first jump, which he followed in combination with a triple toe loop, and his spirits lifted with each successive jump. By the end, the crowd was clapping and yelling to his music, from the opera Carmen, and Lysacek fell to his knees when it was over.  His performance was so spectacular, he beat second-place finisher Ryan Bradley by more than 19 points and three-time national champion Johnny Weir by 35 points.  "My feeling is, you don't dethrone a leader in this sport and Johnny Weir was on top of men's figure skating for quite some time by skating hesitant," Lysacek said. "You go out and fight with passion and just go gangbusters and if I fell on my butt three times, I was going to do it going for the gold."  Weir attempted a quad jump, which he had never landed in competition, but two-footed the landing. He also fell on a triple loop. He had the misfortune of having to skate immediately after Lysacek, so Weir skated onto the ice littered with flowers and stuffed animals in front of a crowd still howling for Lysacek.  "I knew how well Evan must have skated because of the reaction he had and the scores he had and it was very, very difficult to go out after that," Weir said.  Lysacek, Bradley and Weir will represent the United States at the world championships in Tokyo in March.  Initially, Weir did not take his dethroning easily. He sobbed while waiting for his marks, with his coach Priscilla Hill trying to comfort him. But later, Weir took his defeat graciously.  "I'm proud that our U.S. champion skated clean," Weir said. "I know how well I've skated the past three years and I did not want to be beat by something that was sub-par. I'm glad for his first national title that he was able to do the skate of his life because that's how I remember my first national title. Just as long as he doesn't get used to being national champion."  For Bradley, the second-place finish was the breakthrough he has been waiting for. He did not attempt a quad, but skated a clean, exuberant program. When he was finished, he came back on the ice and did a back flip as the crowd celebrated his performance.  "I was just so happy," Bradley said. "This was everything I was hoping to do all season long. I just feel so good to have everyone behind me. I can't really explain it."  Bradley, 23, said he nearly quit the sport several years ago when he began college at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs. He stayed in, but last year he finished eighth in the nationals and completely revamped his skating for this season.  But no one has come further than Lysacek, who is 21. He has finished third in the past two world championships, but without a quad jump in his program he was not considered a threat to skaters like Evgeni Plushenko of Russia or Stephane Lambiel of Switzerland. But neither of those skaters will be at the world championships this year.  To get to worlds, though, Lysacek felt like he needed to conquer nationals and become the top American skater.  And yet, his coach, Frank Carroll, constantly counsels him against thinking about winning.  "It's so like a curse to think about placement," Lysacek said. "Not only is it totally out of your control, but no matter how well you do, it's still not guaranteed. You have to tell yourself, 'Whatever. I've trained for this. I can do this.' "  But when all the training and preparation turned into that victory at last, Lysacek could not control the feeling. He skidded across the ice on his knees when his music ended, overwhelmed by the moment.  "It's hard to put into words how much I wanted to come in here and claim this title," he said.  In the end, he did not need words. The roar said it all.  U.S. FIGURE SKATING CHAMPIONSHIPS
content.title: Lysacek Dazzles His Way to the Men's Title

content.text: ''There's nothing like being hungry for the sport of tennis, and I was really eager and famished, and I needed to feed.''  SERENA WILLIAMS, who won the Australian Open. [15]
content.title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY

content.text: At least there is history for Roger Federer to play against, because for the moment, no man is much of a match.  Fernando González gave it all he had, or at least all he had left, in the final Sunday at the Australian Open. With his forehand working and Federer's slightly off target, the Chilean even managed to serve for the opening set.  But despite all the Latin emotion in motion, the coolest head in tennis once again ruled the evening as Federer defended his title in Melbourne and won his 10th Grand Slam singles title with a 7-6 (2), 6-4, 6-4 victory.  If Federer's opponents hoped that all his success in the past three seasons would leave him feeling sated, his performance here in the year's first Grand Slam event was an unmistakable signal that he remains eager and excellent.  For the first time in his groundbreaking career, Federer swept through a Grand Slam tournament without dropping a set, and the only set points he faced were the two he saved in the first set against González.  It was a terrific set, full of bold shotmaking and lunging defense with González's blocks of fans providing plenty of positive reinforcement for their national icon with their chants of ''Chi-Chi-Chi, Le-Le-Le, Chile! Chile!''  Until this tournament, González had never advanced past the quarterfinals in a Grand Slam event, but with an improved backhand and improved confidence thanks to his new coach, Larry Stefanki, he had broken through by beating four members of the top 20.  Against Tommy Haas in the semifinals, he finished with a stunning 42 winners and just three unforced errors, but a Grand Slam final, particularly against Federer, is a more unnerving proposition. There is the protocol: the photographs at the net beforehand; the aura of gravitas that seeps into the expressions of the officials. It takes time to adjust, and González did a much better job than most debutants. But he could not maintain the same level of excellence. After just eight points against Federer, González already had more unforced errors than in the entire match against Haas. But Federer was also not nearly as sharp early as he had been in his semifinal demolition of Andy Roddick.  Windy conditions sometimes cause him trouble, and there were enough gusts mixed in with the blasts from González to throw him off his rhythm. His deadliest shot is the midcourt forehand, which he can take either direction into the corners, but he failed to convert on several in the early stages of the match. And in the ninth game, González put together two great backhand passing shots in a row to break Federer's serve and earn the chance to serve for the set at 5-4.  At 40-15, after Federer hit a backhand return wide, it looked the Chilean was going to transform this final into something more compelling than the latest Federer coronation. But on the first set point, Federer pushed forward to the net and González hit a hasty forehand passing shot straight at him, which the Swiss volleyed away for a winner. On the second set point, González kicked a first serve to the backhand and was greeted with a deep return. The Chilean responded with an edgy forehand unforced error.  It was deuce, and Federer would soon be back to 5-5, and though González saved four set points of his own on his serve in the 12th game, he could not dig his teeth into the tiebreaker, falling behind 0-5.  The rest was less suspenseful, as is so often the case with one of the best players and front runners in history.  ''He was the better player in the first set,'' Federer said. ''If he closes it out 6-4, it's clear he's the better player in that set. But I came back just at the right moment. I was missing too many forehands, didn't know what to do with his slice. Maybe the wind, maybe his court coverage put me under pressure. I wasn't feeling that great from the start.''  He looked much more at ease from then on, controlling his serve with ease and breaking González in the seventh game of both the second and third sets. He would claim the match and his third Australian Open title by holding his serve at love, shrieking with delight after he hit a backhand winner down the line and then rolling onto his back on the green hard court.  The last man to win here without dropping a set was Ken Rosewall in 1971, and Rosewall was in the President's Box in Rod Laver Arena, looking, as usual, fit and neatly coifed.  ''I'm happy to be the guy who follows up on you; it's a great honor,'' Federer said in his postmatch remarks as he gestured toward Rosewall.  It was a telling moment, because Federer for now has much more in common with the game's former luminaries than his current rivals. He is now, just to take one example, 10-0 against González.  ''I have to congratulate again, again Roger,'' González said, eliciting laughter from the crowd in his post- match remarks. ''He's a great champion. He played a great match today, the whole week and almost all of his life.''  Pete Sampras leads the list with 14 Grand Slam singles titles; Roy Emerson is next with 12, and Bjorn Borg and Laver each had 11. Bill Tilden, like Federer, has 10. But Federer, still only 25 years old, is moving quickly into range, and Sampras has already said he is convinced that the Swiss will pass him.  His only losses in majors the past two years came at the French Open in 2005 and 2006, with last year's defeat to Rafael Nadal of Spain in the final depriving him of a shot at the Grand Slam. But after this performance, the drums will start beating again as the clay court season and Roland Garros approach.  ''Well, I think last year was really the first year I thought if everything goes perfectly well, there might be a chance,'' Federer said of the Grand Slam. ''And I got so awfully close looking back, but the French Open is the second one. It's such a tough one to win. I've given myself chances the last two years, but Rafa has been so dominant on that surface.''  That is true, but Federer has been dominant on everything else.  AUSTRALIAN OPEN
content.title: Federer Makes It Look Easy, Winning 10th Grand Slam

content.text: Shahar Peer did not make it easy, tracking down big shots that others might not have bothered to chase and rallying from a 4-1 deficit in the third set. Serena Williams did not make it easy on herself, struggling with her movement and timing and never looking entirely comfortable.  But in the end, Williams's remarkable Australian Open continued Tuesday with a 3-6, 6-2, 8-6 victory against the determined, fleet-footed Peer, an Israeli, putting her back in the semifinals of the year's first Grand Slam tennis event.  Williams, who won this tournament in 2003 and 2005, will face the 10th-seeded Nicole Vaidisova, a powerful, temperamental 17-year-old who advanced by defeating the 19-year-old Lucie Safarova, 6-1, 6-4, in their all-Czech quarterfinal.  Vaidisova, whose talent was spotted and nurtured early by the International Management Group, has long been considered tennis's next big thing and promoted accordingly. But she began living up to the hype at last year's French Open, where she reached the semifinals after defeating the top-seeded Amélie Mauresmo and Williams's sister Venus.  Now Vaidisova, a tall blonde who was born in Germany, grew up in the Czech Republic and trained in Florida, will have the chance to face another Williams for the first time. She has been watching Serena Williams from close range since Vaidisova was a 12-year-old at Nick Bollettieri's academy.  ''I was definitely a big fan of hers, admired the way she played,'' Vaidisova said.  There has not been much playing to admire in the past two years; Williams has kept her matches and victories to a minimum. She has not reached a final since winning here in 2005. This is only her second event since September, and she arrived in Melbourne ranked 81st amid considerable skepticism about her fitness and commitment. She had a lengthy off-season, which was disrupted by an emotional trial; she and her father, Richard, were involved in a breach-of-contract lawsuit.  But Williams, despite a nagging cold, is now two victories from a third Australian Open title. She has already guaranteed herself a spot in the top 30 in next week's rankings. Although Vaidisova should be the fresher player, that was also true of Williams's four previous seeded victims here: No 27 Mara Santangelo, No. 5 Nadia Petrova, No. 11 Jelena Jankovic and now the 16th-seeded Peer.  ''I'm just happy to be out here and competing,'' Williams said in her on-court remarks to the crowd at Rod Laver Arena, punctuating her sentences with big sips from her water bottle. ''I'm just so excited. Yet another seed!''  This was not nearly the same level of performance as her victory against Jankovic in the fourth round. Williams had 49 unforced errors to 30 winners and put less than 60 percent of her first serves in play against Peer. But she maintained her good habits of serving well under duress and attacking the net effectively.  ''I was just feeling bad for her because she was so flat,'' said her mother and coach, Oracene Price, of the match's early stages. ''And she was getting down on herself. She didn't understand why she wasn't playing better.''  After Peer had clawed back to 4-4 in the third, Williams fell behind, 15-40, on her serve but got back to deuce with consecutive aces. She later saved another in that game with a first serve that Peer could not handle. At 5-5, Williams was down another break point and saved it with a huge first serve and swinging forehand volley that landed on the line.  But Peer, 19, the first Israeli woman to reach this stage of a Grand Slam tournament, held firm on her own serve until the 13th game. Then, at 30-30, Williams nailed a backhand passing shot crosscourt that Peer volleyed long. Peer then missed a backhand on the next point, allowing Williams to serve out the match.  ''She's not quite there and still kicking butt,'' said Price, who expressed pride and mild surprise at her daughter's performance here. She added: ''She's enjoying the competition and really wants to get back. Hopefully now she can stay halfway healthy.''  While the women played in the warmth of the Australian summer on Tuesday, the temperature was much different a few hours earlier when the second-seeded Rafael Nadal finally managed to shake free of Andy Murray, a 19-year-old from Scotland, in the most compelling match of the men's tournament.  For close to four hours in the fourth round, the 15th-seeded Murray and Nadal gave the few thousands fans left in the stands at Rod Laver Arena much more than their money's worth. They turned terrific shots and lunging gets into the coin of their realm as they tested the limits of each other's abilities. When this first match between them had finally ended, Nadal was a 6-7 (3), 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, 6-1 winner, and the prevailing sentiment was that it had better not be their last meeting.  If this is what the next generation has in store, then tennis is in good hands. For now, Nadal, a left-hander from Spain, has the advantage in terms of achievement, and physical and mental strength.  Nadal, 20, has won the past two French Open titles and 15 other tournaments. He has clearly established himself as the world's second-best player behind Roger Federer, whom Nadal happens to have beaten six times in nine matches.  If Nadal had not saved all 10 break points he faced in the final two sets, the match could have been very different.  ''I think this will be one of those matches I'll remember the most,'' said Nadal, who will face the 10th-seeded Fernando González of Chile in the first Australian Open quarterfinal for both.  González eliminated the fifth-seeded James Blake on Monday, 7-5, 6-4, 7-6 (4). Their fourth-round match could have been more compelling if Blake had not failed to convert on three set points in the opening set with González serving at 4-5, 0-40.  Blake, who swept to a title in Sydney this month and appeared in rare form here in the early rounds, also led by 4-2, 40-0 on his serve in the second set. But González caught him from behind again, defeating Blake for a fourth consecutive time.  ''I think that James got a little too angry,'' said Patrick McEnroe, the United States Davis Cup captain. ''He doesn't play well when he gets negative. He plays better when he has fun and he's applauding the other guy's shots. I think he maybe felt the pressure a little bit. He also played a guy as hot as he was.''  The top-seeded player in the women's draw, Maria Sharapova, has recovered well after nearly staggering out of the tournament in 110-degree heat in the first round. On Monday night, she had her troubles but defeated a tricky and resurgent Vera Zvonareva of Russia, 7-5, 6-4.  Sharapova is back in the quarterfinals, where she will face the 12th-seeded Anna Chakvetadze.  TENNIS
content.title: Williams Hangs On to Advance to Semifinals

content.text: MELBOURNE -- When the reinvigorated Andy Roddick stepped on court Thursday to face his longtime tormentor Roger Federer, the consensus at the Australian Open was that spectators were in for a special evening.  That turned out to be true, but not in the way that Roddick, the 15,000 fans in Rod Laver Arena or even Federer himself would have imagined.  Instead of an extended duel between the world's top player and one of his principal rivals, this hotly anticipated semifinal turned into an 83-minute ode to the brilliance of Federer and only Federer.  By the end of the second set, it felt less like a match and much more like a demonstration, as the Swiss continued to break Roddick's huge serve at will and find new and exciting ways to pass the American as he pushed forward, with rapidly diminishing conviction, to the net. The final line: 6-4, 6-0, 6-2.  It was hardly a surprise that Federer beat the sixth-seeded Roddick. He has now won 12 of their 13 matches and all five of their matches in Grand Slam events, but he has never beaten Roddick with this much ease or this much style on a big occasion. In comparison, Federer's four-set victory in last year's United States Open final was a cliffhanger, and when this straight set roasting had been very well done, the debate had been resolved over whether Roddick's recent surge and recent exhibition victory over Federer had closed the gap.  "Look, it's just unreal," said Federer, who will face either Tommy Haas of Germany or Fernando Gonzalez of Chile in Sunday's final. "I'm shocked myself. I don't know what to say. The tournament is not even over yet. Let's not get carried away. Let me try to do it one more time."  Meanwhile, Roddick was once more left to explain how it feels to face tennis greatness, and he did so with a more deft touch than he demonstrated between the lines: offering up mea culpas and compliments and, Roddick still being Roddick, quips. "It was frustrating, you know it was miserable; it sucked; it was terrible," he said. "Besides that, it was fine."  It actually was fine until 4-4 in the opening set. After losing his serve in the opening game of the match, despite putting five of six first serves into play, Roddick recovered to break Federer in the fourth game. But with Roddick serving, something ineffable clicked in Federer's mind and game. At 30-15, the Swiss hit a tremendous backhand passing shot winner. At 30-all, Roddick, just a little edgier, hit a sliced backhand approach shot into the net. And at 30-40, they both ended up at net with Federer winning the battle of reflexes and touch to complete the break.  Roddick did not know it yet, but the match had turned for good. Federer would hold serve at love to close out the set and proceeded to win a total of 11 games in a row and 24 of 27 points at one particularly lopsided stage.  Federer relied on classic shots from his repertoire: forehand flicks that dipped just out of Roddick's reach; running one-handed backhand blasts that zipped down the line; sharply cut volleys that hit the rubberized green surface and quickly bounced twice. But there was also some exotica, none more memorable than the shot produced on the opening point of the fourth game of the second set.  Roddick was already down 0-3, and when Federer gave him a rare short ball, Roddick moved forward and channeled all the frustration of the match's first 40 minutes into a forehand that landed very near the baseline. Most players would have gotten out of the way, but Federer sprung to his left and hit a backhand reflex half volley on the move that traveled cross court for a clean winner. Roddick stood gaping at the net as the crowd roared with a mixture of surprise and aesthetic delight.  But such sounds soon gave way to nervous laughter and anticipatory groans as it became abundantly clear that Roddick had no answers to the tennis riddles that Federer kept posing. Roddick's frustration eventually gave way to anger, and he could not even get that quite right, smashing a ball into the stands after losing his serve and accidentally losing his grip on the racket in the process, sending it hurtling in the direction of a photographer courtside and earning him a code violation for unsportsmanlike conduct.  Even the new electronic line-judging system that Federer dislikes was seeing things Federer's way. The Swiss challenged four times and was correct four times, and when he managed to transform a missed serve into an ace with a challenge while serving at 2-1, 15-0 in the final set, Roddick, who had been convinced the ball had been out, flipped his racket over, stuck the butt against his temple and pretended to pull the trigger.  It was that sort of evening, and it would stay that way as the statistical marvels piled up, with Federer converting on all seven of his break points against one of the world's most feared servers. He also tied Australian Jack Crawford's all-time record, set in 1934, by reaching his seventh consecutive Grand Slam final.  "There is nothing you can really do against someone like that; you just have to shake his hand and say, 'Too good,'" said Australian great Rod Laver, who was in attendance in the arena that bears his name and congratulated Federer in the locker room afterward.
content.title: AUSTRALIAN OPEN: Federer Overwhelms Roddick

content.text: Tommy Robredo of Spain had been vanquished in less style than usual. Andy Roddick was up next in the semifinals, and Roger Federer was sitting comfortably, legs crossed. He spoke a bit wistfully about how great it had been to watch a five-set match the night before, when Rafael Nadal's staying power got the better of Andy Murray's brain power.  ''Very interesting, I thought,'' said Federer, who stayed up late Monday night to see the finish of the Nadal-Murray match on television in his hotel room. ''Raf is incredibly tough. I like to watch him just battle it out. I love seeing that. I mean, he was so strong in the end. He deserved to win.''  For the moment in Melbourne, the small screen is as close as Federer, the world's No. 1 player, has been to a five-set match. Despite fluctuations in form and weather conditions, Federer has not come close to going the distance at this Australian Open.  In five matches, he has not lost a set. Even losing his serve four times, as he did against the seventh-seeded Robredo on a cool, gusty Tuesday night that played tricks with his timing, was not enough to keep Federer from closing out the match, 6-3, 7-6 (2), 7-5.  ''I think he has a level of confidence that is way up there,'' said Robredo, a smooth baseliner who has lost all seven of his matches against Federer. ''He comes up with what he needs.''  Federer has set the bar so high that even straight-set victories can seem deflating if they contain a few too many shots off the frame or a few too many groans of frustration. But the continuing test of a champion is how his game responds to true pressure. Federer has played and won two tie breakers in Melbourne, but it appears from the state of Roddick's mind and form that he could make things much more interesting against Federer on Thursday night, when they meet for the 14th time.  ''I look forward to it,'' Roddick said. ''We've done it before. I'm sure we'll do it again. I feel like I'm in good form. I'd love to see where I match up.''  After fighting his way past the former Australian Open champion Marat Safin in four sets in the third round and past Mario Ancic in five sets in the next round, Roddick conserved some energy Tuesday, when he put friendship aside for 1 hour 27 minutes and overwhelmed his former housemate Mardy Fish, 6-2, 6-2, 6-2. Roddick, who is seeded sixth, kept the celebration to a minimum.  ''You know, it's always difficult; it's a weird, weird situation,'' said Roddick, who made only four unforced errors in the match. ''Being that we're close, I think it takes away maybe a little of the elation because you're not really solely focused on your side of the court. Maybe you're a little more conscious of both sides. It wasn't a planned reaction not to do anything. It was just kind of what I felt.''  A victory over Federer would leave Roddick with no reason to hold back. Theirs, for now, is much more a relationship than a rivalry. Federer has won 12 of their 13 matches; his only loss came in the semifinals of the Masters Series event in Canada in 2003, when he was one victory from claiming the No. 1 ranking for the first time.  ''It was so important for me this experience, this kind of pressure, because never in my life had I handled pressure like this,'' Federer said in recalling that match, which he lost in a third-set tie breaker. ''So I was so disappointed, but so happy to have gone through it later on.''  By the end of the 2003 season, Roddick was ranked No. 1, but Federer had begun to take control of the sport. He has maintained that control for three full seasons, clamping down hard on Roddick in a series of matches in late 2004 and 2005.  But after successfully recruiting Jimmy Connors to help coach him, Roddick has made changes to his backhand and tactics. Above all, he has recovered his sense of the possible.  ''I'll be the first to say it was a welcomed change, almost a new life,'' Roddick said. ''Just the way he put things, it just clicked. I don't know if you can minimize the effect that he's had on me.''  With Connors, the winner of eight Grand Slam titles, in his box and in his corner, Roddick won a set off Federer in last year's United States Open final before losing in four sets. More encouragingly, he held three match points against Federer in a round-robin match at the Masters Cup in Shanghai in November before losing. And he defeated Federer in the final of an exhibition tournament at Kooyong in Melbourne before the Australian Open.  Federer looked anything but devastated, which was understandable. An exhibition is just that, but it could not have hurt Roddick's confidence to have another taste, however diluted, of what it feels like to beat the world's No. 1.  ''Anytime you can get over the hump at all, I think it helps you,'' said John Roddick, who remains his brother's co-coach. ''You're definitely not going to blow it out of proportion, but definitely, you kind of tuck it away in the back of your head and know you can do it.''  Mats Wilander, a three-time Australian Open champion from Sweden, agreed. ''For Roger, losing in Kooyong is nothing, but for Andy, it's huge,'' he said.  Wilander, who won seven Grand Slam singles titles, was one of Roddick's sharpest critics last year here when he was upset in the fourth round by the unseeded Marcos Baghdatis.
