Wilander said Roddick was hitting too hard from too far behind the baseline, was slicing his backhand instead of driving it, and was far too predictable and mechanical in his forays to the net.  A year later, Wilander said he does not find Roddick predictable and likes the way he is hitting through his backhands and taking the ball earlier.  ''I think he has answered the call; I think he answered it already at the U.S. Open,'' Wilander said. ''If you wouldn't have the history behind you, just looking at both Andy and Roger playing here, I'd say this match is 50-50. But because of the history, blah, blah, blah, I'd say it's 60-40 Federer, but I do think Federer has to step it up a little to win this tournament. He still hasn't played a guy who believes he can beat him. I think Andy does and Rafael does.''  TENNIS
content.title: Against Roddick, Federer May Truly Be Tested

content.text: Competitors cannot keep pace with her on the snowboardcross course, but shaking questions about her famous fall at the Winter Olympics has been more vexing for Lindsey Jacobellis.  Since winning a silver medal at last year's Olympics, Jacobellis, a 21-year-old from Vermont, has re-established herself as the dominant athlete in her sport's young history. And Jacobellis is again favored to win the snowboardcross final Saturday afternoon here at the Winter X Games. Qualifying for the event begins Friday.  She was scheduled to compete Thursday night in the women's Snowboard SuperPipe final, but during practice, she fell and sustained a concussion. She pulled out of that event, but is still expected to compete Friday and Saturday in the snowboardcross. She was not a medal favorite in the superpipe, but competes just for fun.  Having fun for Jacobellis has been complicated this year by the ghost of her tumble last year at the Winter Games in Turin, Italy.  ''I'm just kind of over it,'' Jacobellis said during a telephone interview last week from Beaver Creek, Colo., where she won a Jeep King of the Mountain event.  She added, ''I'm probably going to hear all of this hoo-ha for the next four years until the next Olympics.''  All three medalists in the superpipe final on Thursday were Olympians in the halfpipe in 2006. Torah Bright, 20, of Australia was fifth at Turin, but won gold at the X Games with a series of technical tricks.  It was already Jan. 26 in Australia, which is Australia Day, the nation's most important public holiday. Bright called her mother right before her race.  Bright said: ''My mom said, 'Go do it, it's Australia Day.' That, for sure, was the best contest run I've done.''  The Aspen native Gretchen Bleiler, 25, the silver medalist at Turin, won silver here, and Elena Hight, 17, of South Lake Tahoe, Calif., won the bronze. Hight finished sixth at Turin.  Snowboardcross -- a downhill racing discipline in which four or more competitors simultaneously speed through a course of banked turns, jumps, gaps, berms and other obstacles -- was a new event at the 2006 Olympics, and Jacobellis, who had a comfortable lead, appeared to be cruising to its first gold medal.  But on the course's second-last jump, she celebrated early by doing what is known as a method air -- she grabbed her board's heel edge and tweaked it 75 degrees.  It was a mistake.  She landed awkwardly, caught an edge and spun on her back. As she scampered to her feet, Tanja Frieden of Switzerland zipped past her en route to the gold medal. A stunned Jacobellis settled for silver.  The incident, which can be viewed on YouTube, became a big story at the Winter Olympics. It was shown endlessly on television and analyzed in newspaper editorials. The verdict was unanimous, and Jacobellis was condemned: If Jacobellis had not showboated, she would have won.  At first Jacobellis said her stylish grab was an attempt to stabilize in the air, but she later acknowledged she was just trying to have fun.  Last week she called it an unconscious act. ''It was just kind of a fluke thing that happened,'' she said.  She is plainly tired of the subject and would rather allow her accomplishments to speak for themselves. Since winning the 2002 snowboardcross world junior championship, Jacobellis has been dominant.  She was undefeated in World Cup competition during the 2003-4 season, and has won seven of nine World Cup events she has entered since 2004. She has not lost in the last three X Games in which she competed, from 2003 to 2005. Two weeks ago in Arona, Switzerland, she avenged her Olympic loss to Frieden during the semifinals of the world championships and went on to win her second straight world championship.  ''Just to have someone beat me is very rare,'' Jacobellis said, revealing an intense competitor lurking behind a mask of tight blond curls, pale blue eyes and a toothpaste-commercial smile.  Peter Foley, her coach on the U.S. snowboard team, said the incident at the Olympics was hard for her.  ''It's not the way she wanted it to happen, especially being as competitive as she is,'' Foley said. ''Straight up, she's supercompetitive. When somebody is next to her, she will do anything to pass her.''  Jacobellis has also received unconditional support from her teammates on the U.S. snowboard team.  ''We all fall down,'' said Nate Holland, a snowboardcross rider who is also competing at the X Games. ''We all make mistakes. And I think if she had it do again, I think she would have done the method, but she just would have landed it, and there wouldn't have been any question about it.  ''We still to this day throw tricks over the last jump. Hopefully, I'll have enough space here at the X Games and I'll pull a method over the kicker and ride through and show the media the other side of that trick.''  Jacobellis, and those close to her, will tell anyone who asks about her blunder -- and eventually they always do -- how she has since landed on her feet.  ''I still got a silver out of it,'' she said. ''It was pretty amazing.''  EXTREME SPORTS
content.title: A Year After Her Olympic Fall, Winning Is Jacobellis's Revenge

content.text: Few would have imagined, perhaps not even Serena Williams, that when the second week of the Australian Open began, she would still be in contention for the title and the defending champion Amélie Mauresmo would not.  But Williams, in the latest surprising twist in her fiction-trumping life, has quickly gathered momentum and belief after beating two of the better players in the world: fifth-seeded Nadia Petrova of Russia and 11th-seeded Jelena Jankovic of Serbia. Even members of Williams's entourage were shaking their heads in disbelief Sunday night after she had played a fine match from start to finish to beat Jankovic, 6-3, 6-2.  ''I kept hearing she's not in shape,'' Jankovic said. ''But she was running corner to corner and hitting great shots. It just shows that with her, you never know what to expect. You never know.  ''If she plays like she did today, she can maybe even win it.''  That would really be a plot twist, considering how little tennis Williams has played in the past five months, but her draw, so daunting early, is no longer brimming with heavyweights. Nobody else left in her half has been to a Grand Slam final.  ''I like being a dangerous floater,'' said Williams, who arrived here ranked 81st and has guaranteed herself a spot in the top 50 by reaching the quarterfinals.  Her opponent will be 16th-seeded Shahar Peer, the first Israeli to reach this stage in a major tournament. Peer, a determined 19-year-old counterpuncher now being coached part time by José Higueras, upset third-seeded Svetlana Kuznetsova, 6-4, 6-2, after saving two match points against Tatiana Golovin in the third round.  Williams won their only previous match in straight sets, but that was in 2005, before Peer truly took flight. ''She's young and agile and fit, so I have to really be ready,'' Williams said.  The other quarterfinal in her half of the draw will be an all-Czech, all-teenager affair between 10th-seeded Nicole Vaidisova and unseeded Lucie Safarova, a left-hander, who upset Mauresmo, 6-4, 6-3, in the fourth round. In the other half, Martina Hingis advanced to the quarterfinals by beating Li Na of China, 4-6, 6-3, 6-0. She will face Kim Clijsters, who defeated Daniela Hantuchova, 6-1, 7-5.  On Friday, Williams was on the verge of elimination against Petrova. But trailing by one set and 3-5 in the second, she suddenly found her range and stormed back to a three-set victory. Against Jankovic, it was as if Williams was still riding the wave, and this time she was impressive from start to finish.  Jankovic, long ponytail flapping, had beaten Williams in their past two meetings and had had a great deal more success of late. Williams has not reached a final since the 2005 Australian Open. Jankovic reached the United States Open semifinals last year and started this season by winning in Auckland, New Zealand, and coming close to beating Clijsters in the final in Sydney, Australia.  ''She knew that if she didn't come out strong, I'd get on top of her, because I have two wins over her,'' Jankovic said. ''But she did come out strong, and I was feeling a little tired, a little flat.''  Williams took a 3-0 lead before rain forced them briefly off court. When they resumed under a closed roof, Jankovic lifted her play and won the next two games. But Williams, despite the occasional unforced error, did consistent damage on Jankovic's serve, which is the weakest part of her game. Williams broke Jankovic four times and held her own serve all but once, generating the sort of controlled power that no other woman in the game can manage.  ''It's scary,'' Jankovic said. ''When I was looking at the clock, I was seeing 200 kilometers per hour, and I was thinking what would happen if it came too close to my body, and I couldn't get out of the way and it hit me in the stomach. Would it go through me?''  Williams clearly still has the power to intimidate, but the most impressive part of her game Sunday was her ability to hold her own and more in the extended baseline rallies. She is carrying extra weight but still covering the court quite well.  ''I have it in me,'' said Williams, who has not beaten two players of this caliber back to back since she won here in 2005. ''I believe in my game and more than anything I believe in me. It doesn't matter what people say or people write. At the end of the day, I'm my biggest fan. Maybe my dad. But other than that, you have to always be your biggest fan. I'm just working on staying positive.''  Meanwhile, the future of men's tennis and the present of men's tennis remain just that after they exchanged serves and returns Sunday. For all his obvious talent, 19-year-old Novak Djokovic could not take so much as a set from Roger Federer in the fourth round.  Switched on from the start, Federer swooped from baseline to net and back again, thwarting all that big-hitting, two-handed ambition on the other side of the court with his trademark blend of power and finesse to win, 6-2, 7-5, 6-3.  Next up in the quarterfinals for Federer: Tommy Robredo, seeded seventh, a high-energy Spaniard whom Federer has beaten six times in six previous matches.  It has been that sort of tournament thus far for the defending champion Federer, who despite nursing a mild cold has yet to lose a set and yet to become entangled in the traps that this tournament can spring.  While Maria Sharapova, the top-seeded woman, had to find a way to win despite self-described delirium Tuesday as she played in brutally hot conditions, Federer was relaxing on his day off. He did not have to bother with the blustery conditions Sunday because he played Djokovic under a roof because of intermittent drizzle.  Federer's primary rival in the top half of the draw, the American Andy Roddick, has had to slug his way through a rough section: beating the former Australian Open champion Marat Safin in four intense sets Friday, then requiring five more to get past ninth-seeded Mario Ancic on Sunday.  Not that the Australian fans are complaining. They have once again come to Melbourne Park in record numbers despite the opening-day riot between Serbian and Croatian fans, and Roddick's matches have provided some of the best entertainment. He will now provide the tournament with another fine story line in the quarterfinals, in which he faces his childhood friend and former housemate Mardy Fish, the only unseeded man left in the tournament.  But that is not quite as big a surprise as Williams. ''You guys keep burying her, and she keeps coming back to life,'' Mauresmo said as she prepared to head back to France.  TENNIS
content.title: In Another Plot Twist, Williams Is a Contender

content.text: It has been almost a year since Lindsey Kildow had one of the ugliest Olympic downhill crashes since Hermann Maier flew upside down into worldwide fame at the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan. She returned to competition a few days later, but was badly bruised and failed to win a medal.  With the men's circuit in Kitzbühel on Sunday and the women in Italy, the fearless Kildow returned to San Sicario and exacted a measure of revenge by winning a World Cup super-G race on the same slope where her Olympic dreams were dashed a year ago.  ''In ski racing, you're going to have crashes,'' Kildow, 22, said Sunday night in a telephone interview. ''You have to get up and keep going. That's what the difference is between being a long-term winner and a short-term winner.''  Kildow's victory came a week before the start of the Alpine skiing world championships. The 15-day event takes place every other year, this time in Are, Sweden.  Kildow and her United States teammate Julia Mancuso, the Olympic giant slalom champion, are expecting big things. They have been a force on the World Cup circuit this season, each winning three races and remaining in the top five in the overall standings.  Mancuso, who finished eighth Sunday, had an operation to repair hip problems last spring, limiting the time she could spend training and testing equipment before the season.  As nasty as her Olympic fall was, Kildow is no stranger to crashes. Twice this year she has taken hard falls. In October, while training on a glacier in Austria, she sustained a bruised bone below her knee. And a week ago, while racing in Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy, she crashed into the safety nets and missed a day of racing.  ''She crashes because she is always going to her limits, and sometimes a little bit above it,'' said Alex Hoedlemoser, the Austrian-born coach of the United States women's downhill and super-G team. ''That's why she's so fast. If she always skis in the comfort zone, she would always be slow.''  To avoid acknowledging their fragility, the fastest American ski racers have adopted a mordant euphemism for the violent accidents that can occur while racing across bumpy ice at high speed.  They talk about ''visiting the red room,'' a reference to the red safety netting that lines World Cup downhills and wraps around racers in a scary blur as they plow through it toward trees, fans or television cameras.  Kildow recently became engaged to Thomas Vonn, a retired racer from Newburgh, N.Y., who competed for St. Lawrence University before spending several years on the World Cup circuit with the United States team.  Kildow has made a determined effort to learn German, reading children's books to increase her vocabulary. On Sunday, she gave a long and confident interview to Austrian television.  ''The language of skiing is German, and I want to be a part of it,'' Kildow said. ''I'm in the sport for a long time, so I might as well be able to communicate.''  In Kitzbühel, the historic Hahnenkamm races, first held in 1931, took place without the notoriously dangerous Streif downhill.  For the first time since 1971, the weekend event consisted of slalom races. Jens Byggmark of Sweden, an unheralded 21-year-old who had raced in only four World Cup events before this season, won both of them.  Byggmark, a cherub-faced Laplander from the same tiny village as Ingemar Stenmark, the career leader in World Cup wins with 86, was overwhelmed by the prizes and attention that came with winning at the most celebrated site on the circuit.  ''I have no idea what this will lead to; it's really hard to describe,'' said Byggmark, who was overcome by apparently uncontrollable fits of giggling after each of his victories.  The American Ted Ligety, the Olympic combined champion who was seventh Sunday, said of Byggmark: ''He's got a sweet style, a little wild and crazy. It's kind of daunting to think of what we'll have to do to beat him.''  The men's World Cup has one more race before the world championships -- a slalom Tuesday night at Schladming, Austria.  Three slaloms over four days is a unique ordeal for Bode Miller, who has had an outstanding season in the downhill and the super-G but who retains a sentimental attachment to slalom.  Miller wants to formally qualify for the world championship slalom, to try to win that race and become the first racer to win a world championship gold medal in each of the five disciplines. He won the other four in 2003 and 2005.  Five years ago, Miller brought a wacky and effective new style to slalom racing, but he lost his magic as he diversified into an all-event skier, packed on muscle and switched ski manufacturers four times.  He has since found it almost impossible to finish slalom races, but he commands a rapt audience from the top-ranked skiers as he stubbornly starts in every event, suffering through the late start position that comes with his plummeting ranking.  On Sunday, he managed one unblemished performance in the first leg of the race and was less than 10 seconds from the finish on the second when -- in perfect counterpoint to the encouragement of the stadium announcer -- he sprung off course.  SKIING
content.title: Nasty Fall Isn't Keeping Her Down

content.text: Alan Webb, who in 2001 became the only high school miler to run faster than four minutes indoors, will return Jan. 20 to the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan, where he achieved that feat.  Webb's record time of 3 minutes 59.86 seconds came in the New Balance Games. He will run again in that meet in the men's elite mile against James Thie of Wales, Adrian Blincoe of New Zealand, Andy Badderly of England and Jason Lunn of Redwood City, Calif.  Carmen Douma-Hussar of Canada, who won the women's elite mile two years ago, heads the field for that race. Her opposition includes Sara Hall of Palo Alto, Calif.; Amy Mortimer of West Roxbury, Mass.; Marina Muncan of Serbia and Marry Cullen of Ireland.  FRANK LITSKY  SPORTS BRIEFING: TRACK AND FIELD
content.title: WEBB TO RUN MILE IN MANHATTAN

content.text: Bud Delp, the Hall of Fame thoroughbred trainer who saddled the brilliant colt Spectacular Bid, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness in 1979, died last Friday in Ellicott City, Md. He was 74.  The cause was cancer, the Maryland Jockey Club said.  In his 44 years as a head trainer, based in Maryland, Delp had 3,674 winners, ninth on the career list. He won about $41 million in purses and captured stakes races with 70 horses.  Delp won training titles in Maryland, Delaware, New Jersey, Illinois, Florida and Louisiana. He won an Eclipse Award as the nation's leading trainer in 1980 and was inducted into the racing Hall of Fame at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., in 2002.  During the 1960s and '70s, Delp was among the Big Four of Maryland trainers, together with King Leatherbury, John Tammaro and Richard Dutrow. But he had never been a presence in the nation's most prestigious races.  That changed when Delp took charge of the charcoal gray Spectacular Bid, bought for $37,000 as a yearling by Harry Meyerhoff of Hawksworth Farm in Maryland. Delp selected Ron Franklin, a teenager, as Spectacular Bid's jockey, and rocketed with him into the spotlight.  Spectacular Bid won seven of nine starts as a 2-year-old. He captured the 1979 Kentucky Derby and the Preakness with ease, and when Delp saddled him for the Belmont Stakes, he was primed to become the 12th Triple Crown winner in history.  Delp was supremely confident. ''Winning a horse race is never a formality,'' Delp said when Spectacular Bid arrived at Belmont, ''but there's no way he can lose the Belmont Stakes unless he runs into some terribly bad luck.''  Spectacular Bid did run into bad luck, the way Delp told it.  Franklin, 19, sent the colt to the lead briefly in the backstretch, but Spectacular Bid faded and finished third in the mile-and-a-half Belmont, the Triple Crown finale, behind Coastal and Golden Act.  Two days later, Delp said that on the morning of the Belmont, Spectacular Bid went lame when he stepped on a large safety pin that dropped from a leg bandage to the straw of his stall and lodged in his left front hoof. Delp said he removed the pin and suggested that while Spectacular Bid appeared sound, the mishap might have hampered him.  Delp did not criticize the ride given Spectacular Bid, but the inexperienced Franklin might have prompted the colt too early.  Two weeks after the Belmont, Delp replaced Franklin with Willie Shoemaker, and Spectacular Bid went on to win all nine of his starts as a 4-year-old before being retired with 26 victories in 30 races and honors as a champion at ages 2, 3 and 4.  A native of Creswell, Md., Grover Greer Delp, known as Bud since childhood, began working at tracks as a teenager. He saddled his first winner in 1962. Crafty Bear, his last entry, finished third in a stakes race Monday at Laurel Park in Maryland.  Delp is survived by his wife, Regina; his sons Cleve, Doug and Gerald; a daughter, Pajeen; and two grandchildren.  In fall 1980, as Spectacular Bid's retirement neared, Delp reflected on his champion thoroughbred and on his own career.  ''I'm no better trainer now than I was 10 years ago, and that's a damn good one,'' Delp told The New York Times. ''When Bid heads for Kentucky this winter, I won't shed a tear. I'll say, 'Good luck, Daddy,' and I'll bring him a carrot once a year. I did my job. I'll just get right back into the action.''
content.title: Bud Delp, 74, Who Trained Derby Winner Spectacular Bid

content.text: The champion on the way out beat the champion on the way back, and now Kim Clijsters will face Maria Sharapova in the semifinals of the Australian Open.  Clijsters, who has said that this will be her final Australian Open, struggled mightily to control her power for stretches of the first and second sets against the three-time champion Martina Hingis. But in the end, Clijsters's weight of shot and Hingis's lightweight second serve made the difference, as Clijsters broke open a tight match by sweeping the final four games to win, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3.  ''This could have been my last one here; I'm glad I get to play another one,'' said the fourth-seeded Clijsters, who plans to retire from competitive tennis at the end of this season despite being only 23 years old.  Clijsters holds a 4-2 edge over the top-seeded Sharapova, but she lost both of their matches last year in straight sets on hard courts. Neither woman was near her best on this gorgeous, sometimes windy afternoon. Clijsters finished with 62 unforced errors to 47 winners against Hingis, who returned to the sport last year after a three-year break from the game.  As the flubbed returns and double faults piled up for Sharapova against Anna Chakvetadze, Sharapova's coaches, Yuri Sharapov and Michael Joyce, were visibly suffering in the front row.  Sharapov's gesticulations resulted in a warning for illegal coaching midway through the second set as his daughter served at 3-3, 0-30. Sharapov kept his arms folded across his chest for much of the uneven tennis that remained.  Sharapova's 7-6 (5), 7-5 victory required 2 hours 14 minutes -- 11 minutes more than Clijsters's three-set victory -- as the 12th-seeded Chakvetadze kept alternating the sublime (her two-handed backhand) and the ridiculous (a second serve that bounced well before hitting the net in the final set).  ''Sometimes I feel I don't know if she knows what she's doing,'' Sharapova said. ''She definitely has a lot of variety. If she wants to step in, she has a lot of power behind her strokes. But over all, at the end of the day, it's just about who took the chances a little more.''  That has been Sharapova's trademark throughout her career, and it does indeed take preternatural self-confidence to keep taking huge cuts at returns when the results have generally been unsatisfactory.  ''She is stronger,'' said Chakvetadze, a fast-rising blond Muscovite who, at 19, is the same age as Sharapova. ''She's a great fighter. I think she deserves this win.''  But even Sharapova conceded that she will probably have to raise her level if she is to break through to her first Australian Open final. She has come close the last two years, losing to Serena Williams in the 2005 semifinals despite holding three match points and then losing to Justine Henin-Hardenne last year in the same round in a three-set match.  Both Williams and Henin-Hardenne went on to win the title. Williams is still in contention here despite being unseeded. She will face Nicole Vaidisova, a 17-year-old Czech, in Thursday's semifinal in the bottom half of the draw.  Henin-Hardenne withdrew from the tournament for personal reasons. On Wednesday, a posting on her Web site confirmed that she and her husband of five years, Pierre-Yves Hardenne, were separating.  ''These last weeks have not been easy for me or my entourage,'' she wrote. The Web site's name has already been changed from heninhardenne.be to justine-henin.be.  It has been an unusual tournament from the start for Sharapova, who was two points from defeat against the underpowered Camille Pin of France in the first round as temperatures soared well above 100 degrees on court and left Sharapova sluggish and disoriented. Even without being in top form, she has recovered well enough not to drop another set.  Yet she needed more than two hours to beat Vera Zvonareva, 7-5, 6-4, in a night match on Monday in the fourth round. Both Zvonareva and Chakvetadze play terrific defense and are capable of handling Sharapova's power from the baseline.  ''You know, it's tough to be aggressive because Maria, she's hitting the ball so hard,'' Chakvetadze said. ''Especially in the warm-up, I thought she would kill me.''  But once the rallies began in earnest, Chakvetadze held her own. When Sharapova double-faulted to lose her serve and fall behind, 2-4, it appeared that Chakvetadze might do more than that.  But Chakvetadze responded to success by double-faulting herself to lose her serve in the next game, only to have Sharapova do the same again to lose hers.  So it went into the tie breaker, with neither player winning a point on serve until Sharapova managed it at 4-4. On the next point, Chakvetadze glided forward to hit a short forehand and guided it wide.  The set would soon be over, and Chakvetadze's forehand would prove to be vulnerable shot throughout the rest of the match. It did not help her cause that she waited until after the first set to receive treatment for a strained right shoulder.  ''I definitely should have called the trainer earlier,'' she said.  Sharapova received treatment on court for a blister on her left foot in the second set after taking a 4-3 lead in the game in which she received the coaching warning. Sharapov gestured as if he were hitting a forehand from the stands as she fell behind in the game.  The coaching issue is a sensitive one with Sharapova. ''I asked the umpire if it was in between those two points, because between those two points, I didn't see anything or even look at him,'' she said.  Sharapov was not the only father/coach in an agitated mood on Wednesday. Chakvetadze's father/coach, Djambuli, also did little to disguise his mood swings in a different section of the stands.  ''It's normal,'' Sharapova said. ''I've been with my dad every single day, and I'm sure Anna has, as well. They're both animated. Both want you to win, and they're really excited for the opportunities you have.''  TENNIS
content.title: Clijsters and Sharapova Are Out of Sorts, but in the Semifinals

content.text: It has been two weeks of turning back the clock for Serena Williams, and under a closed roof during Saturday's Australian Open women's final, she completed her astoundingly quick trip back to dominance against the top-seeded Maria Sharapova.  Under the lights, she was the relentless Williams of yore: crushing returns and first serves, casting ominous glances across the net and showing not the slightest hint of vulnerability as she raced to a 6-1, 6-2 victory.  The rout, which required just one hour and three minutes, capped one of the most remarkable comebacks in tennis history, and it came against the young, confident woman who will regain the No. 1 ranking on Monday.  But there could be no doubt about who was No. 1 Saturday, as Williams applied enormous pressure from the start and methodically extracted all the suspense to win her eighth Grand Slam singles title and third Australian Open title.  She also won here in 2003 and 2005, and that victory in 2005 was her last in any tournament until this year's unexpected run through a brutal draw in Melbourne. Although Williams arrived here unseeded and ranked 81st, she eliminated six seeded players in her seven matches.  But Williams, the first unseeded woman to win here since the Australian Chris O'Neil in 1978, saved the most prestigious victim for last. When it was over, Williams was jumping up and down with delight, reaching up into the stands to slap hands with her mother and coach, Oracene Price, and eventually dancing in front of her chair. Meanwhile, Sharapova was sitting in hers with tears streaming down her cheeks.  ''You can never underestimate her as an opponent, and I don't think many of you expected her to be in the final, but I definitely did,'' Sharapova said to the crowd in Rod Laver Arena. ''I know what she's capable of. She showed it today. She's an amazing champion, and she showed it here many times, and of course I look forward to playing her many more times, and winning a few, I hope.''  Williams soon began to cry herself when she concluded her rambling, merry victory speech on a serious note as she spoke of her slain half sister, Yetunde Price, who was murdered in September 2003 in Compton, Calif. ''Most of all I would like to dedicate this victory to my sister who is not here,'' Williams told the crowd. ''Her name is Yetunde, and I just love her so much.''  It was a remarkably forceful and focused afternoon for Williams against Sharapova, the 19-year-old who has supplanted her as the sport's dominant personality and commercial enterprise.  Williams finished with 28 winners and 11 unforced errors, a huge success rate for someone who takes such risks with her aggressive game. She broke Sharapova's shaky serve four times and never lost her own, serving seven aces and putting 67 percent of her first serves into play.  ''On the scoreboard, it definitely looked easy, but I was just fighting for every point,'' Williams said in an interview with Australian television.  As the vagaries of Melbourne's weather would have it, Williams has won all three of her titles here indoors. In 2003, the roof was closed because of extreme heat when she beat her sister Venus in three sets to conclude her self-styled ''Serena Slam'' by winning her fourth consecutive Grand Slam singles title. It was closed because of rain in 2005 when she beat Lindsay Davenport after another surprising run through the draw when she, by her own admission, was not in top shape. This year, there were scattered showers in the hour before the match was scheduled to begin, which caused organizers to close the roof again, putting Williams back in a familiar place and frame of mind.  ''When I saw the roof was closed, I said, 'I'm going to win for sure,' '' Williams said with a laugh.  Sharapova became a star by surprising Williams in the 2004 Wimbledon final, handling her power on the grass of the All England Club with baseline power of her own. But Williams had won their most recent match, saving three match points in the 2005 Australian Open semifinals, on her way to the title.  Since then, Williams has struggled with knee problems and personal problems, fighting through depression and distractions and slipping out of the top 100 at one stage last year. All the while, Sharapova was growing into her game and producing consistent excellence in the Grand Slam events, hitting a peak by winning her second major title at last year's United States Open, where Williams was knocked out in the fourth round by Amélie Mauresmo.  There were few hints in recent months that Williams was ready for a breakthrough. She did not play another tournament after the U.S. Open last season, and when she did return to the circuit this month to play a warm-up event in Tasmania, she was beaten in the quarterfinals by a player of limited means: Sybille Bammer of Austria.  Price said the defeat in Tasmania left her daughter in a particularly foul mood. Clearly, Williams still cared, and the matches played there, however uneven, proved useful to her in Melbourne, as she started from a higher platform and made the leap into top form.  ''I think I get the greatest satisfaction just of holding up the Grand Slam trophy and proving everyone wrong; I just love that,'' Williams said. ''I just had so much fun out there today. I just made some great shots. It was just fun.''  This title run did not come without suspense. Williams was down a set and 3-5 in the third round against the fifth-seeded Nadia Petrova before finding her range and roaring back to win. She was also two points from defeat against Shahar Peer of Israel in the quarterfinals, but Williams has played the big points bravely, sometimes ferociously.  Her power and her past still intimidate, even against Sharapova, another fierce competitor who, like Williams, was raised to be a champion, but did not have an older sister along to share the ride and the sacrifices.  But Williams came here without Venus, who withdrew from this tournament, citing continuing problems with an injury to her left wrist. Now, at least one of the Williams sisters is back at the forefront of the sport.  Serena will rise to No. 14 in the rankings on Monday, and she intends to play a relatively full schedule at least through Wimbledon after playing only four tournaments last year.  ''I've been working really hard the last year,'' Williams said, ''and I haven't felt my results have been showing, and finally it all came together at the Australian Open.''  TENNIS
content.title: Williams Shocks Sharapova to Win in Australia

content.text: When 18-year-old Alexa Turzian poled past the finish line of the 10-kilometer freestyle race at the United States Nationals in Houghton, Mich., on Jan. 4, she became the youngest person to win a United States title in cross-country skiing. Her coach, Rick Kapala, was amazed. ''She hadn't been a dominating junior,'' he said in a telephone interview after the race.  In Hailey, Idaho, Turzian's classmates at Wood River High School were incredulous. ''I think they think it seems so unreachable for a young athlete to be national champion,'' Turzian said by telephone last week. ''They just think, 'How is that possible?' ''  Turzian is not on a national team, nor is she a member of a development team. In fact, a year ago, there was no national women's cross-country team because it was thought to have little promise against top international competition. Last year there was no United States women's development team, though teenagers like 19-year-old Morgan Arritola, of Sun Valley, and 18-year-old Liz Stephen, racing for Burke Mountain Academy in Vermont, were winning medals against older women at the nationals.  Instead, leading up to the Turin Olympics in Italy, the United States cross-country team invested its $650,000 budget on five men. ''We made a conscious decision to focus more money on fewer athletes,'' said Luke Bodensteiner, the United States Ski Team's nordic director. ''We took everything we had and put it in play until the Olympics, and if we had to fold up shop after that, then that's what we'd do.''  ''We just went down the world-ranking list,'' said Pete Vordenberg, the cross-country head coach. ''The top-five ranked Americans stayed on our team.''  The all-men's squad included Kris Freeman, who placed fourth in the men's 15-kilometer classic at the 2003 world championships, and Andy Newell, who, after the Olympics, became the first American in 23 years to win a World Cup medal, a bronze in a 1-kilometer freestyle sprint in China.  Others, including Kikkan Randall, had to find outside funding to attract the attention of coaches who were scheduled to name a 17-member Olympic team three weeks before the opening ceremony in Turin. (The United States Olympic Committee -- not the United States Ski Team -- finances the Olympic team.)  For Randall, that meant cobbling together funding from Alaska Pacific University, which paid all her travel expenses and most of her training expenses, and sponsors that included a local dairy and an orthopedic clinic. She also used savings from her part-time job in Anchorage.  Sustained by her fund-raising acumen and an independent training program, Randall made her second Olympic team without competing on the World Cup tour as a member of the national team. She then finished higher than any cross-country skier on the 2006 United States Olympic team, placing ninth in the 1.2-kilometer freestyle sprint. Two weeks later, she had the best World Cup finish by an American woman, fifth in a 750-meter sprint in Sweden.  Turzian, meanwhile, was honing her talent under Kapala's guidance at the Sun Valley Ski Education Foundation, one of the nation's premier clubs. She had just given up an overlapping career as a promising Alpine racer at the same Idaho mountains where the Olympic medalists Picabo Street and Christin Cooper had been groomed.  With solitary focus, Turzian became one of the most driven nordic athletes on her club. Kapala said he received calls from his friends every day saying they saw her roller-skiing the five-mile path to school before dawn or running up mountain trails.  Now she trains 500 hours a year and loves the sport so much that she does most of it on her own.  ''Alexa knows what she wants,'' said her father, Mike Turzian, in a telephone interview. ''She's always wanted to be on the U.S. ski team.''  Recognizing that the sport had been underfunded, the ski team has allocated $1 million of its $24 million net budget this season to cross-country skiing. (The team also finances six other programs: Alpine, snowboarding, freestyle, ski jumping, nordic combined, and disabled skiing.)  The boost in funding has allowed the cross-country team to nearly triple in size. Six athletes are competing internationally on the World Cup (five men and Randall). Eight athletes represent the United States on the lower-tier Continental Cup series. Of the eight, six are women, all under age 23. Bodensteiner and Vordenberg believe the women are poised to make breakthroughs by 2010 and 2014.  ''The challenge will be to keep them going,'' Vordenberg said.  Moments after stepping off the winner's stand at the nationals, Turzian had to return the $1,200 prize money because she will be a freshman at Middlebury College this fall and accepting payment would have violated N.C.A.A. rules.  She also took her first doping test. ''It's kind of weird having someone in the bathroom with you,'' she said. ''But at the same time, it's a good idea. I see why they do it.''  Of all the Olympic sports -- summer and winter -- cross-country skiing ranks third in positive doping tests at the Games since drug testing was started in 1968, in Grenoble, France. Five of the seven positive tests came at the 2002 Games in Salt Lake City, where three athletes had to return medals. ''The sport's not 100 percent clean, for sure,'' said Bodensteiner, who competed in the 1992 and 1994 Games.  Later this month, Turzian will compete at the junior world championships in Tarvisio, Italy, and Randall will be watching. ''It's lonely over here on the World Cup by myself,'' she wrote in an e-mail message from Switzerland. ''I am excited to see other U.S. women stepping up and skiing well. I know we can all get better if we build a team.''  WINTER SPORTS
content.title: Cross-Country Program Picks Up Speed

content.text: In some ways, the United States Figure Skating Championships seem to be in a full post-Olympic-year swoon.  Missing are the two biggest names in women's skating over the past six years, Michelle Kwan and Sasha Cohen, and the men's stalwart Timothy Goebel has retired. So when the event begins today in Spokane, Wash., it will find itself with an unlikely star.  Kimmie Meissner will take the ice a year after her surprising victory in the world championships at age 16 following a sixth-place finish in the Olympics. She was second at last year's nationals behind Cohen. Meissner was nearly forgotten in the attention paid to Kwan's petition to be added to the Olympic team after missing the nationals with an injury.  Meissner, now 17, said she thought it was funny that she was trying to win a national title after capturing a world championship.  ''Yeah, my winning worlds last year was a big shock,'' Meissner said last week from her home in Delaware. ''Winning it before winning nationals is pretty funny. I changed it up.''  She will be the women's favorite at the start of Thursday's short program, most likely vying for the title with Emily Hughes, who eventually took Kwan's place in the Turin Olympics and was another skater who overshadowed Meissner.  If last year marked the end of Kwan's career -- she has not officially retired, but is not competing this season -- it also launched Meissner's. She burst into the sport's consciousness two years ago when she became the first woman since Tonya Harding in 1993 to land a triple axel. Meissner has not landed one since, but she has quietly gone about polishing the artistry of her programs to match the majesty of her jumps.  ''I've probably matured a little bit,'' Meissner said. ''I'm doing my normal triple-triples. I can take on the biggest pieces of music, do different styles. I want to make everything in my program bigger.''  With the glamorous Cohen taking a hiatus from competition, Meissner and Hughes give the top of the women's field a distinctly girl-next-door flavor. Meissner and Hughes are public-school students with a lot of regular-kid interests to go with their top-level skating.  Hughes, who finished seventh in the Olympics and eighth in the world championships at age 17, was trying to write a second chapter in the Hughes Olympic story, after her older sister Sarah's gold-medal performance in 2002.  So far this season, Hughes has finished as high as third, in the Cup of China. Meissner finished second and third in her two international competitions, Skate America and Trophée Eric Bompard.  Meissner called the past year a whirlwind and said she still had not gotten used to people recognizing her. She said she was floored when her local phonebook arrived with her picture on the cover.  ''Now when I go to look up a number, I have to look at my picture,'' she said, laughing. ''It's different, but it's something I definitely enjoy.''  The biggest question mark in the pairs competition, which begins tonight with the short program, is how well John Baldwin will recover from injuries he sustained in a severe beating.  Baldwin and his partner, Rena Inoue, are defending champions at the nationals, and they landed the first throw triple axel in the competition.  They were unsure they could even compete here after Baldwin said he was kidnapped, robbed and beaten while in St. Petersburg, Russia, for a competition in December. He was left with a concussion and vertigo.  ''Thank goodness for skating to help me get through some of the ordeal,'' Baldwin wrote in an entry on the pair's Web site; he added that they resumed training only two weeks ago. ''Our skating is going well and we're performing the throw triple axel every day. I am getting better each day physically and emotionally.''  The men's field will again be led by Johnny Weir, the three-time national champion, who will probably vie with Evan Lysacek for the title.  And the ice-dancing competition will showcase Tanith Belbin and Ben Agosto, the three-time national champions whose silver medal in the 2006 Games was the first Olympic medal by an American dance team in 30 years.  FIGURE SKATING
content.title: Meissner Is Alone on Center Ice

content.text: Anyone who has taken a marathon flight from the United States to Melbourne -- ''Eight movies and you're there'' an Australian once said -- could sympathize with Jimmy Connors as he sat courtside Friday night, having arrived a few hours earlier.  But the huge-hitting, intermittently deep-thinking match between Connors's protégé Andy Roddick and one of the game's unpredictable yet essential men, Marat Safin, was a fine antidote to jet lag. It was only the third round at the Australian Open, but in tone and quality the match was worthy of a much later round. When all the big swings -- emotional and otherwise -- had been completed, Roddick advanced with an impressive 7-6 (2), 2-6, 6-4, 7-6 (2) victory.  ''Jimmy, he's doing a pretty good job with him,'' Safin said.  Connors has spent little time with Roddick in recent weeks because of concerns about his mother and coach, Gloria, who died Jan. 8 at home in Belleville, Ill. But the fruits of Connors's and Roddick's mutual labor in the past six months were on display in Rod Laver Arena. Roddick put his improved backhand and more effective approach shots and volleys to frequent use against his volatile Russian opponent, who won this title in 2005.  ''Obviously, we've been thinking a lot about Jimmy the last couple weeks,'' said Roddick, who came to Australia with his brother John and his trainer, Doug Spreen. ''And for him to be here in the flesh, we're real happy about that.''  This is a court where Roddick has experienced some of the biggest buzzes and busts of his career. It was here that he defeated Younes el-Aynaoui in a 2003 quarterfinal with its epic 21-19 fifth set. It was here that he looked tactically befuddled last year in a stunning loss in the fourth round to Marcos Baghdatis.  But this 3-hour-and-12-minute match, which began outdoors and finished under a closed roof because of rain, was another one to savor. ''From the whole strategic standpoint, this was one of his best matches,'' said Patrick McEnroe, the United States Davis Cup captain. ''This is a different Andy. He comes in now, and he comes in like he means it. He used to come in wondering what he's doing up there. Now you see after he hits his approach, he explodes into net.''  Safin still made him pay on occasion, producing brute force and deft angles with his backhand passing shots. But the sixth-seeded Roddick hit enough acrobatic volleys and touch shots around the net to keep Safin from settling into a groove.  From the backcourt, Roddick held his own, except for one error-filled stretch in the second set and the first few games of the third. His own two-handed backhand, particularly down the line, is a more effective shot now, and Safin, who had split his first six matches against Roddick, gradually realized that some of his longtime tactics against Roddick were not paying dividends, in part because Roddick is covering the court better than in the past while sticking closer to the baseline.  ''Right now, the guy is moving,'' Safin said.  Top-seeded Roger Federer, who is in Roddick's half of the draw, advanced with a straight-set victory over Mikhail Youzhny, last year's flashy United States Open semifinalist from Russia. Federer will face Novak Djokovic, a 19-year-old from Serbia, in the fourth round. Federer's only true difficulties so far have been with the electronic line-calling system, which is being used here for the first time. Federer, a traditionalist, has not been a fan of the system from the start and has yet to show the same gift for challenging calls as he has for whipping forehands.  ''I wish I had none all the time,'' he said of the challenges.  Seventh-seeded Tommy Robredo of Spain put an end to the American youngster Sam Querrey's first Australian Open, 6-4, 6-7 (5), 6-2, 6-1. Querrey, a 19-year-old from California who will break into the top 100 after reaching the third round, roared back from a 2-5 deficit in the second-set tie breaker. But he soon ran low on resources.  ''If I would have just kept running back and forth, I would have cramped,'' Querrey said. ''I was just trying to hit the forehand as hard as I could. He's tough, though. I had to rip 10 shots side to side in order to get a point against him. It was annoying.''  Mardy Fish barely had to sweat at all to reach the fourth round. His opponent, Australia's Wayne Arthurs, lasted only three games before retiring because of the effects of a pain-killing injection for a hip injury that not only deadened the pain, but also caused him to lose temporary control over his right leg. The 35-year-old Arthurs said he would not have taken the risk of an injection if this were not his last Australian Open.  Fish, presumably well rested, will now face 16th-seeded David Ferrer, who erased a two-set deficit against Martina Hingis's fiancé, Radek Stepanek, to win in five sets. Stepanek, a Czech, was back to being a spectator Saturday as Hingis reached the fourth round of the women's event with a 6-2, 6-1 victory over Akiko Nakamura of Japan. Top-seeded Maria Sharapova also advanced, defeating Tathiana Garbin of Italy, 6-3, 6-1.  On the men's side, eighth-seeded David Nalbandian came from two sets down and fended off three match points to beat Sebastien Grosjean, 5-7, 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-4, 6-1  Friday was a trying night for Safin, once the world's No. 1 player before injuries and meandering motivation knocked him back. In the third set, he skinned the pinky finger on his right hand while diving unsuccessfully for a drop shot and required treatment. Before the start of the fourth set, he lost his temper after Wayne McEwen, the tournament referee, insisted he play on after a slight rain delay. Although the roof had been closed, Safin was concerned that the court area outside the lines had not dried, and he spent much of the set expanding on his argument and frustration, in sometimes profane fashion, with McEwen, and the chair umpire, Pascal Maria.  Safin, as is his custom, did not let his rant ruin his rhythm. But Roddick proved to be a fresher, more consistent player down the stretch. After struggling in tie breakers at the end of 2006, Roddick won both handily against Safin.  Darren Cahill, Andre Agassi's longtime coach who is in Melbourne to do television commentary, said there were three big differences in the Roddick of last year and this year. ''Confidence, confidence and confidence,'' Cahill said, laughing.  ''I don't think the backhand is much different. He's just playing it closer up in the court and is willing to take it down the line and willing to pull a few triggers with it,'' Cahill said. ''I think you need the confidence, the ability to make the shot, and once you have that, he's a much more aggressive player. So he's got a good break game at the moment, and we know how good his hold game is. He's a threat, a threat to everyone.''  It is early to start sounding triumphant. Roddick has yet to get past the fourth round in this event, and this year's opponent will be another power player, ninth-seeded Mario Ancic of Croatia. Roddick holds a 4-0 edge in their matches but sees plenty of improvement in Ancic.  ''Mario is a different player now than even when I played him in the semifinals of Wimbledon,'' Roddick said. ''I have the next highest-seeded guy I would have possibly played in the fourth round, so it definitely doesn't get any easier.  ''It started out tough this year,'' added Roddick, who struggled to get past the French wild card Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in the first round. ''I was up against it in the first round, and it seems like it's just going to continue to be that way. Some tournaments are like that, and you somehow just try to survive an event.''  TENNIS
content.title: Roddick Shows His Confidence And Dismantles Safin in a Duel

content.text: Which man deserves the title of America's greatest ski racer ever, Phil Mahre or Bode Miller? It is an argument that warms the sport's fans during many a cold chairlift ride, and the debate breaks along a generational divide.  But as Miller zeroes in on the records Mahre set in the '80s, Mahre has set out to modify his own résumé. This month, Mahre, 49, entered an internationally sanctioned race series at Mammoth Mountain in California.  Competing alongside high school racers as young as 15, Mahre started 85th, when the snow surface was ripped to shreds, making racing slow and painful. He finished second.  Watch your back, Bode.  Mahre, the 1984 Olympic slalom champion, shared the podium with two men born in 1986, two years after he retired. Within hours, coaches of a certain age were reigniting the great chairlift debate, e-mailing the results around.  ''Things have gone well, and in some respects better than planned,'' Mahre wrote recently in an e-mail message from Utah, where he competed last week in four more races. ''Hopefully I can continue on the same upward swing and make this a reality.''  Mahre has set a goal of qualifying for the United States national championships next season, where at 50 he would compete against the whippersnappers on the United States ski team.  This year, he simply hoped to establish a world ranking, but with results like the one in California, it is possible that he will qualify for this year's edition of the championships.  ''Better him than me,'' said Tamara McKinney, Mahre's former teammate, widely considered the country's greatest female racer. ''It's not an easy sport at any age, but Phil's in great shape.''  McKinney, 44, won 18 World Cup races and the overall World Cup title in 1983. She now sells real estate and coaches 10-year-old racers near Lake Tahoe, Calif.  Mahre has neither the intention, nor the joints -- a broken ankle in 1979 required seven screws and a two-inch plate to reconstruct -- to return to racing's most elite circuit, but his modest comeback is noteworthy because it coincides with Miller's assault on his position as the top American on the World Cup career victories list.  On Saturday, Miller crashed through the finish line to win the prestigious Lauberhorn downhill here, giving him his 25th career World Cup victory, two behind Mahre's American record.  Asked about chasing Mahre, Miller said: ''I don't think of him that often. Obviously, he was a great champion. The U.S. hasn't had many of those. He stands out in history of U.S. skiing as one of the few guys who really competed and won at the top level a significant number of times.''  Mahre also showed little concern about having his record broken by Miller -- whom he has criticized in the past. Miller is skiing strong now, a year after he failed to win medals in the five events he entered at the Olympic Games last year in Turin, Italy.  Those in Mahre's corner point to the three years (1981-83) when he won the sport's most prestigious trophy, the overall World Cup title. Miller did it only once, in 2005.  While Mahre was a ''technical specialist,'' racing giant slalom and slalom, Miller does every event, passing up chances to rest and train, and once swept victories in each of the sport's disciplines in a record 16-day stretch.  Both are known for strong opinions and fearless independence.  There have been sea changes in ski equipment since Mahre retired, some of them driven by Miller's experimentation. But Mahre has kept pace by running the Mahre Training Centers, a race camp.  The digital revolution has been harder to keep pace with. In Mahre's heyday, the United States team used a massive video camera and tripods so they could watch race video. Now, even junior racers travel with laptops, downloading World Cup footage that they compare side-by-side with video of their own skiing.  One of the most important weapons in a skier's arsenal is video analysis software that allows them to chart their speed fluctuations and to overlay images of themselves in different training runs. The United States ski team even has a super-slow-motion camera that reveals problematic vibrations of the ski that are invisible to the unassisted eye.  For now, Mahre takes the more old-fashioned approach of the ''Rocky'' movies of his day: He trains really, really hard.  ''I haven't done much video stuff,'' he said in a telephone interview earlier this winter. ''For me, it's just volume -- getting 12 runs on a course and three or four more freeskiing. If you're on top of your game, you can go back and do quality work, but for me it's quantity.''  Adam Chadbourne, the head coach at Vermont's elite ski school, the Burke Mountain Academy, invited Mahre to train with the team on a Austrian glacier and said Mahre blew the teenagers away as he lapped them on the training course's chairlift.  ''He was a great inspiration to them,'' Chadbourne said.  That approach is apparently already putting Mahre on track for his goal.  ''He's an incredible athlete, just the way Bode is,'' said James Cochran, a United States ski team racer. ''It sounds like he's going to make nationals. Hopefully he won't beat us.''  Cochran descends from the Cochran clan of Vermont that won a heap of Olympic and World Cup medals in the seventies. He races on the World Cup now, so he views the who's-the-greatest debate from an authoritative perspective.  ''Bode is definitely the Phil Mahre of our time,'' Cochran said.  SKIING
content.title: A New Hill to Descend

content.text: MELBOURNE -- Roger Federer was sitting comfortably, legs crossed, after vanquishing Tommy Robredo in less style than usual in the quarter final round of the Australian Open Tuesday. He was talking just a little wistfully about how great it had been to watch a five-set match the night before when Rafael Nadal's staying power had gotten the better of Andy Murray's brain power.  "Very interesting, I thought," said Federer, who had stayed up late on Monday night to see the finish on television in his hotel room. "Raf is incredibly tough. I like to watch him just battle it out. I love seeing that. I mean he was so strong in the end. He deserved to win."  For the moment in Melbourne, the small screen is as close as Federer is getting to five-set fever. Despite fluctuations in form and weather conditions, the world's number one player has not come close to going the distance at this Australian Open.  In five matches, he has not lost a set, and even losing his serve four times, as he did against the seventh-seeded Robredo on a cool, gusty Tuesday night that played tricks with timing, was not enough to keep Federer from closing out the smooth-moving Spanish baseliner 6-3, 7-6 (2), 7-5.  "I think he has a level of confidence that is way up there," said Robredo, who has lost all seven of his matches against Federer. "He comes up with what he needs."  Federer has set the bar so high that even straight-set victories can seem deflating if they contain a few too many errant shots or a few too many groans of frustration.  But the ongoing test of a great champion is how his game responds to true pressure, and though Federer has played and won two tiebreakers in Melbourne, it appears that Roddick's form and the American's state of mind could make things more interesting for Federer when the two face off for the 14th time on Thursday night.  "I look forward to it," Roddick said. "We've done it before. I'm sure we'll do it again. I feel like I'm in good form. I'd love to see where I match up."  After having to fight his way past former Australian Open champion Marat Safin in the third round in four sets and Mario Ancic in the next round in five sets, Roddick got to conserve some energy on Tuesday as he put close friendship aside for an hour and 27 minutes and overwhelmed his former housemate Mardy Fish 6-2, 6-2, 6-2 and then kept the celebration to a minimum  "You know, it's always difficult; it's a weird, weird situation," said Roddick, who made a minuscule four unforced errors in the match. "Being that we're close, I think it takes away maybe a little of the elation because you're not really solely focused on your side of the court. Maybe you're a little more conscious of both sides. It wasn't a planned reaction not to do anything. It was just kind of what I felt."  A victory over Federer would leave him with no reason to hold back. Theirs, for now, is much more a relationship than a rivalry. Federer has won 12 of their 13 matches, his only loss coming in 2003 in the semifinals of the Masters Series event in Canada when Federer was one victory away from claiming the number one ranking for the first time.  "It was so important for me this experience, this kind of pressure, because never in my life had I handled pressure like this," said Federer, who lost in a third-set tiebreaker. "So I was so disappointed but so happy to have gone through it later on."  By the end of the 2003 season, Roddick had the number one ranking but Federer had begun taking control of the sport, and he has maintained that control for three full seasons, clamping down hard on Roddick in a series of matches in late 2004 and 2005.  But after successfully recruiting all-time great Jimmy Connors to help coach him, Roddick has made changes to his backhand and tactics and, above all, recovered his sense of the possible.  "I'll be the first to say it was a welcomed change, almost a new life," Roddick said. "Just the way he put things, it just clicked. I don't know if you can minimize the effect that he's had on me."  With Connors in his corner, Roddick took a set off Federer in last year's United States Open final before losing his edge in the fourth. More encouragingly, he held three match points against the Swiss in a round-robin match at the Masters Cup in Shanghai in November before losing, and then beat him in the final of an exhibition tournament in Melbourne before the Australian Open.  Federer looked anything but devastated, which was understandable. An exhibition is just that, but it could not have hurt Roddick's confidence to get another taste of what it felt like to beat the Swiss.  "Anytime you can get over the hump at all I think it helps you," said John Roddick, who remains his brother's co-coach. "You're definitely not going to blow it out of proportion, but definitely, you kind of tuck it away in the back of your head and know you can do it."
content.title: AUSTRALIAN OPEN: Roddick Will Try to Make Semis Interesting for Federer

content.text: In 2001, Alan Webb broke the high school indoor and outdoor records for the mile and became the first prep runner to run a sub-four-minute mile indoors. Then came six years of occasional fast times interrupted by too few good races and too many injuries and illnesses.  As Webb saw it, it was six years of going hardly anywhere.  There were teases. In 2005 in Oslo, he ran a mile in 3 minutes 48.92 seconds, fast by any standard. Last year, at Stanford, he ran 10,000 meters in 27:34.72, the fastest debut by an American. But he felt his potential was untapped.  ''I'm a miler,'' Webb said. ''The last few years, I've tried other stuff, like distances and cross-country. Now it's time to see where I am in the mile.''  He was glowing after his 3:56.70 mile last Saturday at the Armory in Upper Manhattan, his fastest indoors. Tonight, over the even-faster 200-meter track at the Reggie Lewis Center, he will run the mile in the Boston Indoor Games against Chris Lukezic, Gabe Jennings and Rob Myers of the United States; Kevin Sullivan and Nate Brannen of Canada; Ivan Heshko of Ukraine; and Elkanah Angwenyi of Kenya.  ''I'd like to keep improving,'' Webb said. ''I think with the competition in Boston, I'll probably have to run at least what I did last week or faster.  ''I am very happy with my condition. Last year, I was in very, very good shape in the late spring and early summer, but I tweaked my hamstring and got a little bit sick, a little bit tired, and things didn't really work out in the summer. But that training did not go away, and I am reaping the benefits of the training I've done the last few years.''  He said one objective was to train exactly enough.  ''I feel like a lot of times, you have to walk that line between doing too much and doing too little,'' he said. ''You really have to toe it as close as you can.  ''Sometimes you do too much. Last year was a pretty good example of that.''  Webb is 24, 5 feet 9 inches and 140 pounds. He comes from Reston, Va., and, after one year at the University of Michigan, he returned home to resume training with Scott Raczko, his coach from the start.  Webb opened his season with a 3:59.34 mile in Fairfax, Va. Ahead are the mile in Boston tonight and the Wanamaker Mile in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden next Friday. After that may be the Tyson Invitational on Feb. 10 in Fayetteville, Ark., and the national indoor championships Feb. 23-25 in Boston.  He is especially looking forward to Millrose, the blue-ribbon meet indoors.  ''What makes Millrose great,'' Webb said, ''is running in Madison Square Garden and running in front of a crowd of 10,000 or 15,000 people and running against the best guys in the world. Just being in a race with Bernard Lagat and Craig Mottram, that could be the Olympic 1,500-meter final. It's that kind of level.  ''I wouldn't go in if I didn't think that I could compete. Spectators only want to see me if I'm running well. They don't want to see me get ninth or something.''  TRACK AND FIELD
content.title: Feeling Healthy and Ready, Webb Takes Aim at the Mile

content.text: After two rounds of watching a rookie play the big room at the Buick Invitational, Tiger Woods finally cleared his throat Saturday on the South Course at Torrey Pines. For more than four hours, Woods elbowed his way past competitors and made a steady climb up the leader board until he had whittled a seven-stroke deficit to two.  Woods, who is bidding for his seventh PGA Tour victory in a row, shot a three-under-par 69 to trail the rookies Brandt Snedeker (74) and Andrew Buckle (68) by two shots in his 2007 debut.  The veteran Kevin Sutherland (70) was one shot behind Snedeker and Buckle, while Charles Howell III (73), Troy Matteson (69) and Bill Haas (72) also trailed the leaders by two shots. Mark Calcavecchia (68) was among a group of seven players who stood three shots back. Snedeker and Buckle were at 11-under-par 205.  Woods, with 3 birdies in his first seven holes and 11 pars to close out the round, quickly changed the dynamic of the tournament, which he has won four times, including the last two years. During the third round, many of the players who had been well out in front of Woods were aware of his rise up the leader board.  Some of the fans in the gallery even made it a point to tell Snedeker, who opened the tournament with a 61 and has owned at least a share of the lead for three rounds.  ''You know it's coming,'' Snedeker said of Woods's emergence. ''I think everybody out here knows he's going to play well. It was not a shock at all. I hope he goes out there and plays a great round tomorrow, and I hope I go out there and beat him by one. That would be the best scenario ever.''  When Sutherland made birdie on the 18th hole, he pushed Woods out of the final group and into the penultimate group, a fact not lost on Snedeker, 26, and Buckle, 24, who is from Australia.  Snedeker and Buckle will be paired instead with the 42-year-old Sutherland, whose lone Tour victory came at the 2002 Match Play Championship.  ''I need to send him a thank-you note,'' Snedeker said of Sutherland. ''I would love to play in the last group with Tiger, but as a rookie, I'm glad the way it worked out.''  Buckle, who twice won the Junior World Golf Championships at Torrey Pines, agreed that there would be plenty of time to play alongside Woods in the future.  ''I think I would have been pretty nervous,'' Buckle said.  The catalyst for Woods's move up the leader board was a sparkling short game. He was a little scattered with his driver and irons, missing 11 of 14 fairways and landing in 9 bunkers, but he manufactured pars with his putter.  Woods and Nick Watney (70) were the only players who did not make a bogey Saturday.  ''I dropped some key putts to keep the round going and keep momentum going and, basically, keep me in contention,'' Woods said. ''It's nice to be in contention the first week out. That's why I prepared as hard as I did, to put myself in this spot.''  Much of Woods's mastery in his career has come when he has led going into the final round. Only 16 of his 54 tournament victories have come after trailing through three rounds. But he knows the nuances of Torrey Pines as well as anyone on the leader board.  He does not, however, know much about the competitors he will face Sunday.  ''There are a lot of new guys out here,'' Woods said. ''You go out on the range and there's a bunch of new faces.''  He finally met Snedeker on Saturday morning, when they bumped into each other on the practice green before the third round. At last, Woods was face to face with the player who had been edging him out of the spotlight.  ''Tiger said hello to me on the putting green, which is pretty phenomenal,'' Snedeker said. ''I didn't think he knew who I was and he said, 'Brandt, great playing.'  ''Somebody told me he's had 41 more wins than I've had starts on this tour. I think he's got me beat in that aspect. I know he's going to be there down the stretch. It's just a matter of keeping my wits about me and learning how to play golf.''  GOLF
content.title: Rookies Hear Rustle of Woods's Footsteps in the Grass

content.text: The Austrian skier Hermann Maier, who knows a thing or two about bouncing back from injury, has offered encouragement to the Austrian-born governor of California, Arnold Schwarzenegger, who broke a leg last month on a skiing trip.  ''I wrote him a letter,'' Maier said in an interview Sunday. ''I told him I believe for sure he will have a great comeback.''  In the late 1990s, Maier's aggressive skiing and seemingly indestructible body earned him the nickname the Herminator, a play on the title of Schwarzenegger's most famous action-movie character, the Terminator.  Maier was already one of the greatest ski racers when he nearly lost a leg in a 2001 motorcycle accident. He then returned to the top of the sport two years later, winning skiing's most coveted trophies with a mellower, more reflective attitude.  Now losing speed at 34, Maier has not said when he plans to retire. He won two medals last year at the Olympic Games in Turin, Italy, but this season has finished on the podium only once in 15 races on the World Cup circuit.  He typically peaks for the annual Hahnenkamm race at Kitzbühel, Austria, the most dangerous and celebrated downhill on the tour. That Jan. 27 event could be canceled as early as tomorrow if race officials decide there is not enough snow.  With dirt showing through much of the course's lower section, organizers are importing snow from higher elevations with trucks and helicopters.  Schwarzenegger, who broke his right femur Dec. 23 in Sun Valley, Idaho, is an avid skier. Maier has never skied with him, though he said he hoped to.
content.title: Herminator Encourages Governator

content.text: The mentoring program in American tennis has its limits, as Alex Kuznetsov discovered soon after breaking James Blake's serve twice at the beginning of their second-round match at the Australian Open.  Kuznetsov's 3-0 lead quickly became a 6-4, 6-1, 6-2 defeat Thursday as Blake, his occasional counselor, raised his game and then raised it some more, packing a high percentage of spectacular shots into 1 hour 21 minutes of indoor tennis at Rod Laver Arena.  Blake's pate remains bald and shiny, but his beard gets thicker and he has no intention of shaving it until he loses. ''Superstition,'' Blake said sheepishly. ''It starts to look silly.''  Blake is 6-0 in 2007 after sweeping to the title in Sydney. Judging from his form in his first two matches here, it could be a while before he has to reach for a razor.  After handling Carlos Moyá in an intense straight-set match Tuesday, he manhandled Kuznetsov, a 19-year-old American who was one of the world's brightest prospects until he crashed a rented sports car borrowed from a friend into a tree in May 2005 in Tampa, Fla., and broke his right leg.  ''Being stupid, trying to drive too fast,'' said Kuznetsov, who has a titanium rod in his leg. ''I am very lucky, very lucky to be playing tennis.''  It was four months before he could resume hitting, but Kuznetsov has shown encouraging signs of revival here, making it through qualifying and winning his first Tour-level match in the first round of the main draw against Peter Luczak of Australia in five late-night sets.  But the fifth-seeded Blake, the highest-ranked American player, was too big a step up. Blake appears to have lifted his game a level in the off-season and is returning serve particularly well in Melbourne. Moyá won just 31 percent of the points on his second serve and Kuznetsov won fewer than 20 percent.  There was little chance that Blake was going to take Kuznetsov lightly. He knows him well after training with him frequently in Florida at Blake's invitation.  ''It's not like him playing somebody he doesn't know,'' Blake said. ''He knows the pace, he knows how well I can move, he knows kind of the things I can do. It's almost a little frustrating.''  Consider that the price of giving back to the next generation, which is something that Blake and Andy Roddick have done regularly, just as Andre Agassi, Todd Martin and Pete Sampras did it for them.  ''I don't feel ancient, but I guess in tennis years I am,'' the 27-year-old Blake said. ''When I can help out, whether it's hitting with them, whether it's taking them out to a meal and trying to teach them about being a little bit more professional on Tour, anything, it's my pleasure. That's a role that I take seriously.''  Kuznetsov also used Blake for a role model as he tried to come back from his injury. Blake had his own annus horribilis in 2004 when he broke his neck during an on-court tumble, lost his father to cancer, then contracted shingles.  But he is seeing the ball clearly now, and there were moments when Kuznetsov had to wonder what it would take to win a point when he was not giving one away with an overeager unforced error. There were fine approach shots from Kuznetsov that Blake transformed into lunging, full-swinging forehand winners. There was an excellent drop shot that Blake turned into an angle winner, and there was even a good overhead early in the third set that Blake trumped with a leaping reflex forehand well above his head that got over Kuznetsov and ended up giving Blake the point.  There is still much to improve in a Grand Slam setting, however. Next, Blake will face the German qualifier Mischa Zverev or another good American friend, Robby Ginepri.  But the most anticipated match of the round will not involve Blake. It will involve Andy Roddick and the former Australian Open champion Marat Safin. Roddick, seeded sixth this year, advanced with a straight-set defeat Wednesday of Marc Gicquel of France. Safin defeated the Israeli qualifier Dudi Sela with much more difficulty, 6-3, 5-7, 4-6, 7-5 (4), 6-0, taking control of the match only after the roof on Vodafone Arena was closed because of light rain.  Roddick and Safin have split their six previous matches, and though Safin is seeded 26th, Roddick has no illusions about what sort of threat he poses, particularly after Safin led Russia to the Davis Cup title in Moscow in December.  ''You're asking someone who are their top six or seven favorites for this event, you know, I feel like his name is in there still,'' Roddick said. ''If Marat is match tough, I don't think there's any question of his standard.''  Roddick's protégé is also in the third round. Sam Querrey, a 19-year-old Californian, continued to enjoy his first Australian Open by defeating Florent Serra of France, 6-3, 6-4, 6-3, on Wednesday night.  It was a poised and convincing performance, and it earned Querrey a match with seventh-seeded Tommy Robredo.  ''Just going to go out there and hit winners; that's the game plan right there; there's no secret,'' said the 6-foot-6 Querrey, who has trained frequently with Roddick, most recently in Kona, Hawaii, before this tournament.  There were no shortage of winners on Wednesday night as Gaël Monfils of France knocked out Marcos Baghdatis, last year's surprise finalist and sentimental favorite, in four sets in the second round.  But as the twisting, turning match reached its unexpected conclusion under a closed roof, it appeared that the Australians had found another emotive, unpredictable 20-year-old to embrace.  With his elastic limbs, mind-blowing defense and leaping shot-making, Monfils, like Baghdatis, is about as self-contained as an N.F.L. cheerleader. But unlike Baghdatis, Monfils did not have a small legion of friends, relatives and fellow Cypriots and Greeks in attendance to provide positive reinforcement. He did not even have a coach, having fired his second coach in five months, Pier Gauthier, after arriving in Melbourne for the tournament.  ''I was thinking this was like the film 'Troy,' '' Monfils said before the match. ''The story of a guy all alone against an army. I'm going to have to put the few Australians there are in the crowd in my pocket.''  Mission accomplished. As for the women, No. 2-seeded Amélie Mauresmo played a fine, up-tempo night match to defeat Olga Poutchkova, a young Russian who is based in New York, 6-2, 6-2. Serena Williams also continued to address her rust problem and beat the Luxembourg veteran Ann Kremer, 7-6 (4), 6-2, which earned her a date with fifth-seeded Nadia Petrova.  Williams, overweight and short on matches, will not be the favorite. Neither will Monfils against Richard Gasquet, his fellow Frenchman and longtime measuring stick, but it is hard to believe after that serve and all that verve on Wednesday night that Monfils will not be the crowd favorite.  Baghdatis is gone, after all.  TENNIS
content.title: After Falling Behind Early, Blake Quickly Regains Place
